commit_message:
Fixed issues with Murano Engine integration tests

We have some issues with internal MuranoCI and this
commit introduces several fixes for issues with
floating IPs, port connectivity checks and evironment
deployment verification.

Closes-Bug: #1338992
Change-Id: I7bf206330ab783bba08a2b121c6353e360c52317

added_lines: self.user = user self.password = password self.auth_url = auth_url def clear_floating_ip_pool(self): # we use print function for output, because Jenkins # will ignore all data from logging. for tenant in self.auth.tenants.list(): nova = novaclient.Client(self.user, self.password, tenant.name, self.auth_url, service_type="compute") try: floating_ips = nova.floating_ips.list() print("Tenant {0} has the following floating IPs: {1}". format(tenant.name, floating_ips)) for ip in floating_ips: if str(ip).split(',')[2] == ' instance_id=None': nova.floating_ips.delete(ip) print("Removed floating IP from pool: {0}.".format(ip)) except: print("User {0} hasn't access to tenant {1}.". format(self.user, tenant.name)) self.clear_floating_ip_pool()

commit_message:
Fix openstack releases version

The Fuel 5.1 will be destributed with two openstack versions:

* 2014.1.1-5.1 -- for new envs
* 2014.1.1-5.0.2 -- for patching old envs

The release 2014.1.1-5.1 don't should be capable to update old
environments, so we need remove them from the release fixture.

Change-Id: Iddf41c41cc519c8abdd9493e27ea52088d96001e
Blueprint: upgrade-to-5-1

'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2014-07-17 19:43:33.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/96b6d07b4989a62f581482439a0d4e638b8d757d', 'message': 'Check for resize path on libvirt instance delete

If an instance is deleted after the instance's disk image path has
been renamed by adding the "_resize" suffix to it but before the
resize operation completes, the libvirt driver will not delete the
orphaned files and manual intervention is needed to get them deleted.

This fix addresses the issue by attempting to rename the instance path
by adding a "_del" suffix and if that fails, renaming the instance path
with the "_resize" suffix by replacing the "_resize" suffix with the
"_del" suffix.  If both renaming operations fail, the sequence is
repeated, in case the the disk image path initially had the "_resize"
suffix and another thread removed it before the second rename operation
was attempted. These rename operations are used in favor of checking
for the existence of paths and deleting if found, because rename
operations are atomic whereas another thread could rename the path
between the exist check and the deleting.

Regardless of the outcome of the renaming operations, the existence of
the instance path with the "_del" suffix is verified and if it exists,
it is deleted. This is done in case a prior delete operation that
managed to create the "_del" path was subsequently interrupted before
all instance files could be deleted.

Note that the LibvirtConnTestCase.test_delete_instance_files test case
was removed in order to eliminate redundancy.

Closes-Bug: #1308565

commit_message:
Check for resize path on libvirt instance delete

If an instance is deleted after the instance's disk image path has
been renamed by adding the "_resize" suffix to it but before the
resize operation completes, the libvirt driver will not delete the
orphaned files and manual intervention is needed to get them deleted.

This fix addresses the issue by attempting to rename the instance path
by adding a "_del" suffix and if that fails, renaming the instance path
with the "_resize" suffix by replacing the "_resize" suffix with the
"_del" suffix.  If both renaming operations fail, the sequence is
repeated, in case the the disk image path initially had the "_resize"
suffix and another thread removed it before the second rename operation
was attempted. These rename operations are used in favor of checking
for the existence of paths and deleting if found, because rename
operations are atomic whereas another thread could rename the path
between the exist check and the deleting.

Regardless of the outcome of the renaming operations, the existence of
the instance path with the "_del" suffix is verified and if it exists,
it is deleted. This is done in case a prior delete operation that
managed to create the "_del" path was subsequently interrupted before
all instance files could be deleted.

Note that the LibvirtConnTestCase.test_delete_instance_files test case
was removed in order to eliminate redundancy.

Closes-Bug: #1308565

Change-Id: Ifcb2e18211347ccf3e5472779c5917a729a6eced

added_lines: @mock.patch('os.path.exists') @mock.patch('nova.virt.libvirt.utils.get_instance_path') def test_delete_instance_files(self, get_instance_path, exists): lv = self.libvirtconnection lv.delete_instance_tree = mock.MagicMock(return_value=True) get_instance_path.return_value = '/path' instance = instance_obj.Instance(uuid='fake-uuid', id=1) # Ensure method is called only once exists.side_effect = [True] result = lv.delete_instance_files(instance) self.assertTrue(result) lv.delete_instance_tree.assert_called_with('/path', instance) get_instance_path.assert_called_with(instance) @mock.patch('os.path.exists') @mock.patch('nova.virt.libvirt.utils.get_instance_path') def test_delete_instance_files_resize(self, get_instance_path, exists): lv = self.libvirtconnection lv.delete_instance_tree = mock.MagicMock(return_value=True) get_instance_path.return_value = '/path' instance = instance_obj.Instance(uuid='fake-uuid', id=1) exists.side_effect = [False, True] result = lv.delete_instance_files(instance) self.assertTrue(result) lv.delete_instance_tree.assert_called_with('/path_resize', instance) get_instance_path.assert_called_with(instance) @mock.patch('os.path.exists') @mock.patch('nova.virt.libvirt.utils.get_instance_path') def test_delete_instance_files_failed(self, get_instance_path, exists): lv = self.libvirtconnection lv.delete_instance_tree = mock.MagicMock(return_value=False) get_instance_path.return_value = '/path' instance = instance_obj.Instance(uuid='fake-uuid', id=1) # Ensure method is called only once exists.side_effect = [True] result = lv.delete_instance_files(instance) self.assertFalse(result) lv.delete_instance_tree.assert_called_with('/path', instance) get_instance_path.assert_called_with(instance) @mock.patch('os.path.exists', return_value=False) @mock.patch('shutil.rmtree') def test_delete_instance_tree(self, rmtree, exists): lv = self.libvirtconnection instance = instance_obj.Instance(uuid='fake-uuid', id=1) result = lv.delete_instance_tree('/path', instance) rmtree.assert_called_with('/path') self.assertTrue(result) @mock.patch('os.path.exists', return_value=True) @mock.patch('shutil.rmtree') def test_delete_instance_tree_failed(self, rmtree, exists): lv = self.libvirtconnection instance = instance_obj.Instance(uuid='fake-uuid', id=1) result = lv.delete_instance_tree('/path', instance) rmtree.assert_called_with('/path') self.assertFalse(result) @mock.patch('os.path.exists', return_value=True) @mock.patch('shutil.rmtree', side_effect=OSError()) def test_delete_instance_tree_exception(self, rmtree, exists): lv = self.libvirtconnection instance = instance_obj.Instance(uuid='fake-uuid', id=1) result = lv.delete_instance_tree('/path', instance) rmtree.assert_called_with('/path') self.assertFalse(result)

commit_message:
Fixes incorrect exchange lock in fake driver

The exchanges lock in the fake driver was being disregarded,
probably due to a typo.

Closes-Bug: #1342088

commit_message:
Use module subprocess instead of module commands

According to https://docs.python.org/2/library/commands.html
the commands module is deprecated since Python version 2.6 and has
been removed in Python 3. The commands module should not be used
anymore.

Change-Id: Ifceaa2379273a53374cc9505ddd7f5af498d81a5

deleted_lines: import commands status, output = commands.getstatusoutput(cmd) LOG.debug(output) self.assertEqual(0, status)

added_lines: execution_db = _create_execution(workbook_name, task_name, input) return execution_db return task_db def stop_workflow(self, execution_id): db_api.start_tx() try: execution_db = db_api.execution_get(execution_id) state = execution_db['state'] if not states.is_valid_transition(state, states.RUNNING): LOG.info("Can't change workflow state [execution_id=%s," " state=%s, new state=%s]" % (execution_id, state, states.RUNNING)) return execution_db db_api.execution_update(execution_id, {'state': states.STOPPED}) LOG.debug('Stopped workflow [execution_id=%s]' % execution_id) db_api.commit_tx() finally: db_api.end_tx() db_api.start_tx() try: execution_db = db_api.execution_get(execution_id) state = execution_db['state'] if not states.is_valid_transition(state, states.RUNNING): LOG.info("Can't change workflow state [execution_id=%s," " state=%s, new state=%s]" % (execution_id, state, states.RUNNING)) return execution_db db_api.execution_update(execution_id, {'state': states.RUNNING}) LOG.debug('Resumed workflow [execution_id=%s]' % execution_id) db_api.commit_tx() finally: db_api.end_tx()

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/01/108301/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SUCCESS = 'SUCCESS' ERROR = 'ERROR'_VALID_TRANSITIONS = { IDLE: [RUNNING, ERROR], RUNNING: [STOPPED, DELAYED, SUCCESS, ERROR], STOPPED: [RUNNING, ERROR], DELAYED: [RUNNING, ERROR], SUCCESS: [], ERROR: [] } def is_invalid(state): return not is_valid(state) def is_valid_transition(from_state, to_state): if is_invalid(from_state) or is_invalid(to_state): return False if from_state == to_state: return True return to_state in _VALID_TRANSITIONS[from_state]

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # # Copyright 2014 - Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. from oslo.config import cfg from oslo import messaging from mistral import context as auth_ctx from mistral.openstack.common import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class EngineClient(object): """RPC client for the Engine.""" def __init__(self, transport): """Construct an RPC client for the Engine. :param transport: a messaging transport handle :type transport: Transport """ serializer = auth_ctx.RpcContextSerializer( auth_ctx.JsonPayloadSerializer()) # TODO(rakhmerov): Clarify topic. target = messaging.Target(topic=cfg.CONF.engine.topic) self._client = messaging.RPCClient( transport, target, serializer=serializer ) def start_workflow(self, workbook_name, workflow_name, task_name, input): """Starts a workflow execution based on the specified workbook name and target task. :param workbook_name: Workbook name :param task_name: Target task name :param input: Workflow input data. :return: Workflow execution. """ kwargs = { 'workbook_name': workbook_name, 'task_name': task_name, 'input': input } return self._client.call(auth_ctx.ctx(), 'start_workflow', **kwargs) def on_task_result(self, task_id, task_result): """Conveys task result to Mistral Engine. This method should be used by clients of Mistral Engine to update state of a task once task action has been performed. One of the clients of this method is Mistral REST API server that receives task result from the outside action handlers. Note: calling this method serves an event notifying Mistral that it possibly needs to move the workflow on, i.e. run other workflow tasks for which all dependencies are satisfied. :param task_id: Task id. :param state: New task state. :param result: Task result data. :return: Task. """ kwargs = { 'task_id': task_id, 'task_result': task_result } return self._client.call(auth_ctx.ctx(), 'on_task_result', **kwargs) def stop_workflow(self, execution_id): """Stops the workflow with the given execution id. :param execution_id: Workflow execution id. :return: Workflow execution. """ kwargs = {'execution_id': execution_id} return self._client.call(auth_ctx.ctx(), 'stop_workflow', **kwargs) def resume_workflow(self, execution_id): """Resumes the workflow with the given execution id. :param execution_id: Workflow execution id. :return: Workflow execution. """ kwargs = {'execution_id': execution_id} return self._client.call(auth_ctx.ctx(), 'resume_workflow', **kwargs) def rollback_workflow(self, execution_id): """Rolls back the workflow with the given execution id. :param execution_id: Workflow execution id. :return: Workflow execution. """ kwargs = {'execution_id': execution_id} return self._client.call(auth_ctx.ctx(), 'rollback_workflow', **kwargs) class ExecutorClient(object): """RPC client for Executor.""" def __init__(self, transport): """Construct an RPC client for the Executor. :param transport: Messaging transport. :type transport: Transport. """ serializer = auth_ctx.RpcContextSerializer( auth_ctx.JsonPayloadSerializer()) # TODO(rakhmerov): Clarify topic. target = messaging.Target(topic=cfg.CONF.executor.topic) self._client = messaging.RPCClient( transport, target, serializer=serializer ) # TODO(rakhmerov): Most likely it will be a different method. def handle_task(self, cntx, **kwargs): """Send the task request to Executor for execution. :param cntx: a request context dict :type cntx: MistralContext :param kwargs: a dict of method arguments :type kwargs: dict """ return self._client.cast(cntx, 'handle_task', **kwargs)

subject: Add option for end-user to format volume on create

Change-Id: If4f6ad2bd1255d7ed4bfca9efd234c3aca58610c

commit_message:
Add option for end-user to format volume on create

This proposal is to provide an option to cinder-create
that allows a user to have the volume partitioned and
formatted at create time, which will enable the volume
to then also be auto-mounted to the instance it's being
attached to.

Change-Id: If4f6ad2bd1255d7ed4bfca9efd234c3aca58610c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/09/99809/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== optional-format-on-create ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/optional-format-on-create Provide an option on volume creation to pre format the volume with a file system so it can be auto-mounted to a Nova instance. Problem description =================== Currently Cinder strictly provides raw block devices, which is great. The current workflow is: * cinder create * attach to instance * log in to instance and: - partition device - format device - mount device Cinder already has the capability to do things like attach a volume on the Cinder node and do things like xfr a boot image to it. Or clone the contents of another volume to it. It would be useful for a number of users to be able to actually specify a formatted volume at create time and also be able to instruct the attach process in Nova to actually mount it as well. This is just a "helper" to make things a bit more automated for end-users, but also could be extended to do things like setup multi-attach volumes with an appropriate FS. Proposed change =============== Add options to "cinder create" that allow a user to partition a volume as well as format it with a filesystem. We don't need to cover every possible FS or partition scheme but just pick some of the most common (ext3/4, xfs)? Options for partitioning can be provided via a set of basic partition schemes that could be selected from (similar to Nova's flavors). Formatting options could just be an option passed in via the create call. "cinder list-partitions" uuid: "Linux-LVM" uuid: "Linux-Extended" .... Formatting options would be limited to some basic commonly used FS's like ext-3/4, xfs So the "cinder create" call could look like: "cinder create --partition <Linux-LVM-UUID> --format ext4 \ --name my-formatted-vol 100" We'd use the existing internal cinder attach mechanisms to attach the newly created volume to the Cinder node, partition it and format it (similar to how we deal with loading images to a bootable volume, or cloning etc). The next step would be to add a mechanism to Nova's attach to allow specification of a mount point and have the volume auto-mounted. Alternatives ------------ You could do all of this on the compute side, but that's a bit messy and incurs risk of accidental formatting of a Volume that has data on it. The other option is just leave it as it is currently and leave all fo this as a manual process for the end user, but that's not an alternative, it's just accepting the status quo and ignoring the problem. Data model impact ----------------- Should be able to implement this without modifying the data model if preferred. Options here include using volume-metadata to mark it as formatted or do the same sort of thing we do with bootable and update the data model to include a "formatted-on-create" flag. REST API impact --------------- Example JSON schema definition { "volume": { "availability_zone": null, "source_volid": null, "display_description": null, "snapshot_id": null, "size": 10, "display_name": "my_volume", "imageRef": null, "volume_type": null, "metadata": {}, "partition": None, "format": None } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Just makes life slightly easier Performance Impact ------------------ Adds some time to the create process if selected, but it's optional so if you don't want the time penalty don't use it. Other deployer impact --------------------- Shouldn't have an impact as it's a create option only Developer impact ---------------- Existing mechanisms for "create volume from image" are listed as required, so we should have all of the capabilities needed to do this in a generic manner that covers all existing/compliant drivers. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- John Griffith Work Items ---------- Implement the partition and format code in Cinders base driver Implement the API call in existing Cinder create Implement the required changes to python-cinderclient * Add capability to Nova's attach command to auto-mount (non-cinder task, and is not a requirement) Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests Functional test added to Tempest/Gate Documentation Impact ==================== Added options to cinder create References ==========

commit_message:
libvirt: add parsing of NUMA topology in capabilities XML

Introduce classes to nova.virt.libvirt.config for parsing
the NUMA topology information in the capabilities XML
schema.

Blueprint: virt-driver-numa-placement
Change-Id: I4948514cf38268663cdcf4bb31f335a19a7ec9d1

commit_message:
Pull-request: Decouple read chunk size from write chunk size

These changes are necessary for
I4e0c563b8f3a5ced8f65fcca83d341a97729a5d4 , to make decoupling be
complete for all existing store drivers and fully fixing bug #1336168
since vmware vsphere store could copy from any store but http.

This stuff needs to be ported to glance.store as well, IMO.

Change-Id: Ie41f2fa05217ffd8180dc34960f2aae844335f5b
Signed-off-by: Zhi Yan Liu <zhiyanl@cn.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Implements new 'bootable' option for manage existing volume.

A 'bootable' option (defaults to False) can be passed as part of
the HTTP POST request to manage an existing volume.  This is
passed into the database when the volume is created.

Also changes all drivers to use the more agnostic keys
'source-name' or 'source-id' when specifying
which existing volume to manage.  This change is to support the
cinderclient change in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/76216/
to make it easier for CLI users to manage existing volumes
without having to know the implementation-specifics of the driver.

Change-Id: I58eaa75181fd0b606628584308fd83bdeaa8b64f
Implements: blueprint add-export-import-volumes

alarm REST notifier does not have retry function: notification simply fails,
for example, when the receiver is down. With this patch, retry function
for alarm REST notifier is added.

Unfortunately, there is a case that the receiver succeeds in processing alarm
notification, but fails to return the http response.
In this case, alarm notifier need to retry. By setting a unique request-id
(in http request header) for each notifications (same id across retries),

commit_message:
Add retry function for alarm REST notifier

The alarm REST notifier does not have retry function: notification simply
fails, for example, when the receiver is down. With this patch, retry
function for alarm REST notifier is added.

In some cases, alarm notifier can not get response even if the receiver is
working fine (e.g. temporarily lost connection, failing over).
Currently, alarm notifier give up to notify in that case.
So, this patch introduces ability to retry to alarm notifier.

By setting a unique request-id in HTTP request header (same id on retry),
the receiver can decide if the notification is new or redundant.

Change-Id: I29ee910e5beb5669377baaaa2810044a7c40d9ad
Closes-bug: #1329716

commit_message:
Fixes Cinder volume upload to image on windows

Due to fact that when uploading a volume to an image the file is
opened in text mode and the different line endings style on
windows glance client won't be able to upload the desired file.
The solutions is to simply open the file in binary mode when
performing this action.

Change-Id: I51b084ce38e1aaad4ded63b75b097137dedc088c
Closes-bug: 1346911

commit_message:
Reorder the old compatibility arguments

The registration for --os-cert, os-cacert, and os-key were moved
recently into a new method. We need to register the new versions
(which have default values set) before the old compatible versions
(--os_cert, etc.) that have no default values set or the default
values which pull from the env variables (OS_CERT, etc.) get
ignored.

Change-Id: I4bfb89d02909176be420dd978f8235d94978c494

commit_message:
Remove low-value logging from publication codepath

Previously, the pipeline publish codepath emitted log messages
with almost no diagnostic value other than a "comfort bump".
However the sheer volume of these message was overwhelming
logstash in the CI gate.

We remove the worst offenders from that codepath.

Change-Id: If630593e8f755ccc1ede16941459daac30d284ff
Closes-Bug: #1328596
(cherry picked from commit 5f8a1fbf804c9572b777eb6af3d24cf9a98df758)

greenio 0.6 is the first version supporting trollius, and it requires at

For your information, I am the maintainer of the trollius project and I

Change-Id: I564e6eb6842cfb0d7f4c29a319071667a695e99a

commit_message:
Add greenio dependency

The greenio project will be used in OpenStack to support executing
trollius coroutines in greenlet. The first user will be the Oslo
Messaging project: see the "greenio executor" spec (accepted for Juno).
Later, at least Ceilometer will be modified to use explicit trollius
coroutines instead of implicit eventlet greenthreads.

greenio 0.6 is the first version supporting trollius, and it requires at
least trollius 1.0.

For your information, I am the maintainer of the trollius project and I
am working with Yury Selivanov on greenio. I am also working directly on
the tulip project and asyncio in Python 3.4 and 3.5.

blueprint greenio-executor

Change-Id: I564e6eb6842cfb0d7f4c29a319071667a695e99a

commit_message:
stop leaking service as a global var

the tls code was leaking out $service as a global variable, which
was causing all manner of confusing errors in grenade trying to
use that variable name. All lower case vars should be localize.

Change-Id: I74fa597f20ee7c714cab83490b42d874ea93db02
(cherry picked from commit f0bd8dbe37bd855669ad4cddff0a49bccfd9b64e)

commit_message:
Add differencing vhdx resize support in Hyper-V Driver

Differencing VHDX images can be resized, unlike differencing VHD images.
Even so, the Nova Hyper-V driver currently does not support this.

This feature is required for resizing existing instances which use CoW
VHDX images and also in order to resize the root disk image when
spawning a new instance.

The methods which get the internal maximum size of a vhd/vhdx
image have been updated to lookup the parent disk and get the according
size instead of raising an exception in case of differencing images.

Change-Id: I867a9b35e5273b96afc443e5c436a15d0c45161b
Implements: blueprint add-differencing-vhdx-resize-support

commit_message:
API v1.1 - Encapsulate message post bodies in a JSON object

This patch implements one of the breaking changes specified in
the API v1.1 spec, which requires clients to encapsulate the
list of messages to enqueue in a JSON object, when posting
those messages to the API.

Partially-Implements: blueprint api-v1.1-request-document-changes
Change-Id: I72ae87e1c479b6be6fbc8ce1fbaee89b2729e41a

commit_message:
Fix error when update a router created before dvr

If update a router created before dvr patch, following exception occurs,
because router['extra_attributes'] is None.

The patch check extra_attributes, if it is None, try to create the
corresponding database entry.

Change-Id: I16e619d4d0783fa3fa6122f005fbd246b7b8a3d6
Closes-bug: 1346902

subject: Storwize/SVC: Fix races in host-related functions
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-08 21:07:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/c55fc632063c81545250ab73fd64144bf77d9d17', 'message': 'Storwize/SVC: Fix races in host-related functions

In the Storwize/SVC driver, initialize_connection checks if a host
object exists on the storage, and if not, creates one. Similarly,
terminate_connection checks if there are any more mappings for this
host, and deletes the host object if there are none. Consequently, there
exist races between two initialize_connection calls, two
terminate_connection calls, or one and one.

The easy solution here is to use locks. Because locks are files on the
local machine, this implies that all cinder-volume processes managing a
given Storwize/SVC contoller run on the same machine.

Change-Id: I62cd992e7150e7d16f1a2b2be6ef61c64b638858

The easy solution here is to use locks. Because locks are files on the
local machine, this implies that all cinder-volume processes managing a

Change-Id: I62cd992e7150e7d16f1a2b2be6ef61c64b638858
Closes-Bug: #1274123
'}]
commit_message:
Storwize/SVC: Fix races in host-related functions

In the Storwize/SVC driver, initialize_connection checks if a host
object exists on the storage, and if not, creates one. Similarly,
terminate_connection checks if there are any more mappings for this
host, and deletes the host object if there are none. Consequently, there
exist races between two initialize_connection calls, two
terminate_connection calls, or one and one.

The easy solution here is to use locks. Because locks are files on the
local machine, this implies that all cinder-volume processes managing a
given Storwize/SVC contoller run on the same machine.

Change-Id: I62cd992e7150e7d16f1a2b2be6ef61c64b638858
Closes-Bug: #1274123

commit_message:
Clear entries in Cisco N1KV specific tables on rollback

During rollback operations, resources are cleaned up from neutron
database but leaves a few stale entries in the n1kv specific tables.
This change addresses the proper clean up of tables. i.e. VLAN/VXLAN
allocation tables, profile binding and vm network table.

Change-Id: I7a09d34f3a9dee0a43b76c5d781ee9eb9938953a
Closes-bug: #1336596

commit_message:
call security_groups_member_updated in port_update

When a running VM is added to a security group, all existing VMs (ports)
in the security group should be notified/updated - otherwise they would
have incorrect rules, not knowing the new VM/port added.

The current behavior would only update the port of the added VM. This
patch forces an security_groups_member_updated() call for all the
security groups that have ports removed or added.

Change-Id: Ibdcd74f47043762386b62f3ec0fa1723060446ac
Closes-Bug: 1316618
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/93/101293/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Wire API models to policy engine

Previously, the API was wired to dummy data models.  We now initialize
the policy engine and API together from congress_server.py

Note: you must set the policy_path param in
congress/etc/congress.conf.sample for the server to work properly.

Change-Id: I6ae855fc217dc2401035b6c9f89d1d6607f8ac10

commit_message:
Revert "Split ExtraConfig into compute + control"

We need to retain backwards compatibility, so this isn't the right
way to go with this.

Also - there is no need to add extra environment variables, as the
extra config data can just be written to the heat environment file.

This reverts commit fbd8039ac978f67926faeadd4b0d6a4c4010705a.

Change-Id: I6ec3593cdebba27625b1cb3c9da0a3bbfc907ea4

added_lines: # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. heat $HEAT_OP -e $TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud-env.json \
deleted_lines: OVERCLOUD_COMPUTE_EXTRA_CONFIG=${OVERCLOUD_COMPUTE_EXTRA_CONFIG:-$OVERCLOUD_EXTRA_CONFIG} OVERCLOUD_CONTROL_EXTRA_CONFIG=${OVERCLOUD_CONTROL_EXTRA_CONFIG:-$OVERCLOUD_EXTRA_CONFIG}# NOTE: Temporary change to allow HEAT template patches to land. # Change-Id: Ieaee80e414130504a5e40e878a5a4ca1c196ca2b. if grep -q "Ref:\s*ExtraConfig" $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-heat-templates/overcloud.yaml; then # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. heat $HEAT_OP -e $TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud-env.json \else # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. heat $HEAT_OP -e $TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud-env.json \ -t 360 \ -f $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-heat-templates/overcloud.yaml \ -P "NovaComputeExtraConfig=${OVERCLOUD_COMPUTE_EXTRA_CONFIG}" \ -P "ControllerExtraConfig=${OVERCLOUD_CONTROL_EXTRA_CONFIG}" \ $STACKNAME fi

commit_message:
Spec API validation

Implements api-validation:
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/api-validation

Change-Id: Ib439444a594cb68717a61f3d224af2afb2295145
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/congress refs/changes/60/104360/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============== API Validation ============== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/congress/+spec/api-validation Users (and programs) sometimes provide invalid inputs to APIs. The API should be resilient to this, and deny bad requests. Problem description =================== Any request that does not conform to the form expected by the API is deemed invalid. Invalid requests should be rejected by the API, along with information to aid in correcting the problem. The following features are desirable in an API validation solution: * Validation should enforce a declarative model that is visible external to the validation implementation. * The declarative model should follow standard formatting and conventions that are understood in the API caller's context. * For cross-platform APIs, the model should be consumable without knowledge of a particular programming language. * The model should provide sufficient information for generation of resource documentation in associated API reference material. * Validation should be performed by a common framework which facilitates binding the declarative models with the API implementation. * The API implementation may assume trusted inputs by relying on the framework to offload validation. * Validation may be selectively enabled on API outputs to facilitate development and testing. Proposed change =============== We will introduce JSON schemas to model the expected inputs and outputs of each API call. The API resource manager will be updated to support binding of schemas to each handler. When dispatching API calls, the framework will validate the call body using the 'jsonschema' python validator. If an optional flag is provided, the dispatcher will validate the API handler response body before passing the response up the stack. Alternatives ------------ Other components, such as neutron, have created custom validation utilities. These utilities are often not as rich as JSON schema, and do not address many of the desirable features described above. The nova project is currently retrofitting their API to utilize JSON Schema validation: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/v3-api-schema Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- The current API provides very minimal validation. This change will add validation to all existing API calls. Security impact --------------- Adding validation to the API should increase security of the system by protecting the API implementation from unexpected inputs. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ Validation of inputs will have a negative performance impact on latency and throughput of API calls. JSON schema does not necessarily impose larger performance impacts than other validation solutions, despite its increased power and flexibility. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- After introduction of API validation, new API calls will need to introduce an associated schema. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: pballand Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Create JSON schemas for each API resource (This is already done in the API design, and simply needs to be translated to the source tree.) * Add support to the API resource manager to bind schemas with resource endpoints. * Add jsonschema as a runtime dependency. * Use jsonschema to validate requests before dispatching to API implementation. * Expose flag to support output validation. Optionally use jsonschema to validate body of API result before returning to the wsgi server. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= The schema validator is assumed to be thoroughly tested. We will test that validation is being performed by issuing requests that should and should not validate against the schema. Documentation Impact ==================== This change itself does not impact documentation. The addition of schemas for each API call should be included in the documentation. References ========== JSON Schema definition: http://json-schema.org/ Python jsonschema validator: https://python-jsonschema.readthedocs.org/en/latest/ Nova spec for updating validation to use JSON Schema: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/v3-api-schema

Use auth_token from keystonemiddleware

been moved to the keystonemiddleware repo.

commit_message:
Use method's logger in log decorator

Previously decorators shared logger. This patch makes LOG object in
closure for every decorated method in order to use correct logging
level.

Closes-Bug: #1340778
Change-Id: If907acbab34f8bf23e1277e66c3ddd839f668764
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/99/106399/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG = logging.getLogger(method.__module__)

commit_message:
Cleaning up grammer and wording, avoiding 2nd person

Updating description of encrypted live migration process to avoid 2nd person
perspective, cleaning up grammer and wording to improve clarity.

Change-Id: Ibf0cfac2a4f6c592269c5921397aa3a70c1db4ab
Closes-Bug: #1344374
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/55/108855/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>If there is a sufficient business case for keeping live migration enabled, then libvirtd can provide encrypted tunnels for the live migrations. However, this feature is not currently exposed in either the OpenStack Dashboardor nova-client commands, and can only be accessed through manual configuration of libvirtd. The live migration process then changes to the following high-level steps: 1) Instance data is copied from the hypervisor to libvirtd. 2) An encrypted tunnel is created between libvirtd processes on both source and destination hosts. 3) Destination libvirtd host copies the instances back to an underlying hypervisor.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>If your use case involves keeping live migration enabled, then libvirtd can provide tunneled, encrypted live migrations. That said, this feature is not currently exposed in OpenStack Dashboard, nor the nova-client commands and can only be accessed through manual configuration of libvirtd. Encrypted live migration modifies the live migration process by first copying the instance data from the running hypervisor to libvirtd. From there an encrypted tunnel is created between the libvirtd processes on both hosts. Finally, the destination libvirtd process copies the instance back to the underlying hypervisor.</para>

commit_message:
Add link to management security domain to security guide

Migration network section needs link to management security domain (just in
case reference is needed), and then changing indeed to with as it's currently not a comprehensible sentence.

Change-Id: Iab1468bb15f823e4695e32b1b06a7e65d402ad85
Closes-Bug: #1344361
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/security-doc refs/changes/51/108851/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>As a general practice, live migration traffic should be restricted to the management security domain (http://docs.openstack.org/security-guide/content/security-boundaries-and-threats.html). With live migration traffic, due to its plain text nature and the fact that you are transferring the contents of disk and memory of a running instance, it is recommended you further separate live migration traffic onto a dedicated network. Isolating the traffic to a dedicated network can reduce the risk of exposure.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>As a general practice, live migration traffic should be restricted to the management security domain. Indeed live migration traffic, due to its plain text nature and the fact that you are transferring the contents of disk and memory of a running instance, it is recommended you further separate live migration traffic onto a dedicated network. Isolating the traffic to a dedicated network can reduce the risk of exposure.</para> </section>

commit_message:
Clarify usage of SWAuth

While discussing SWAuth as one of the Identity providers for Swift, it was
not explicit that SWAuth could be used only with Swift. This checkin
clarieis that.

Change-Id: I125e4aad36c55acfd6c6afc7b69e4e14d9275301
Closes-Bug: #1342386

commit_message:
Return a tuple of None's instead of one None

The expected return value of _commit_port_binding is something that
can be unpacked into two values. This changes the condition where a
concurrent delete was detected to return a 2-tuple of None's
instead of a bare None to prevent an iterable error.

Closes-Bug: #1342880
Change-Id: I9d3a51eab33819ffda6a65a00c3b5d1006a3577e

commit_message:
Store clients in context

Having the Stack create the Clients object means that custom constraints
do not have access to the already created clients. This greatly
complicates test mocking, and results in unnecessarily created
constraint-scoped clients.

This change makes the Clients be created in RequestContext on demand.
Constraints use the Clients associated with the context.

Mocking client create calls is simplified, generally needing to
call _create once instead of MultipleTimes()

Change-Id: If67e2d6761003558b32909c4655fadb4d0630b86

commit_message:
Avoid possible timing attack in metadata api

Introduce a constant time comparison function to
nova utils for comparing authentication tokens.

Conflicts:
	nova/utils.py

Closes-bug: #1325128
Change-Id: I7374f2edc6f03c7da59cf73ae91a87147e53d0de
(cherry picked from commit 4a60c6a655006b2882331844664fac5cf67c5f34)

commit_message:
Ensures listener queues exist in fake driver

The fanout queues of the fake driver are created at the first executor
poll, but if we use eventlet executor and the fake driver, when the sender
delivers a fanout message before the first poll, the message goes to the
topic queue instead of the server fanout queue.

The changes fixes that by ensuring the all queues exists when the
listener is created.

Closes bug #1331453
Related-Bug: #1334798

Co-authored-by: Paul Michali <pcm@cisco.com>
Change-Id: I92e7c01dd87d634b741bbcaea92f48730fdd555e
(cherry picked from commit e582da68f4c5edd3e4a3cdb62819c210c72dcfad)
(cherry picked from commit 0cfafac2468afe6b601a985495382aae3351b217)

added_lines: # NOTE(sileht): Ensure that all needed queues exists even the listener # have not been polled yet for target in self._targets: exchange = self._exchange_manager.get_exchange(target.exchange) exchange.ensure_queue(target) def ensure_queue(self, target): with self._queues_lock: if target.server: self._get_server_queue(target.topic, target.server) else: self._get_topic_queue(target.topic)

Assert the respective schema.""" doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=params.get('weight', 10), uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017") ) shard_name = params.get('name', "newshard") self.addCleanup(self.client.delete, url='/'+shard_name) result = self.client.put('/'+shard_name, data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 201) # Test existence result = self.client.get('/'+shard_name+'?detailed=true') self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 200) self.assertSchema(result.json(), 'shard-detail') @ddt.data( { 'name': "newshard", 'weight': 10, 'uri': "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017" } ) def test_delete_shard(self, params): """Create a shard, then delete it. Make sure operation is successful. """ # Create the shard doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=params.get('weight', 10), uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017") ) shard_name = params.get('name', "newshard") result = self.client.put('/'+shard_name, data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 201) # Make sure it exists result = self.client.get('/'+shard_name) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 200) # Delete it result = self.client.delete('/'+shard_name) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 204) @ddt.data( { 'name': "newshard", 'weight': 10, 'uri': "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017" } ) def test_list_shards(self, params): """Add a shard. Get the list of all the shards. Assert respective schema """ doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=params.get('weight', 10), uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017") ) shard_name = params.get('name', "newshard") self.addCleanup(self.client.delete, url='/'+shard_name) result = self.client.put('/'+shard_name, data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 201) result = self.client.get() self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 200) self.assertSchema(result.json(), 'shard-list') @ddt.data( { 'name': "newshard", 'weight': 10, 'uri': "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017" } ) def test_patch_shard(self, params): """Create a shard. Issue a patch command, make sure command was successful. Check details to be sure. """ doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=params.get('weight', 10), uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017") ) shard_name = params.get('name', "newshard") self.addCleanup(self.client.delete, url='/'+shard_name) result = self.client.put('/'+shard_name, data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 201) # Update that shard patchdoc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=5, uri="mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017" ) result = self.client.patch('/'+shard_name, data=patchdoc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 200) # Get the shard, check update# result = self.client.get('/'+shard_name) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 200) self.assertEqual(result.json()["weight"], 5) @ddt.data( { 'name': "newshard", 'weight': 10, 'uri': "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017" } ) def test_patch_shard_bad_data(self, params): """Issue a patch command without a body. Assert 400.""" # create a shard doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=params.get('weight', 10), uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017") ) shard_name = params.get('name', "newshard") self.addCleanup(self.client.delete, url='/'+shard_name) result = self.client.put('/'+shard_name, data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 201) # Update shard with bad post data. Ensure 400 result = self.client.patch('/'+shard_name) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 400) @ddt.data( { 'name': "newshard", 'weight': 10, 'uri': "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017" } ) def test_patch_shard_non_exist(self, params): """Issue patch command to shard that doesn't exist. Assert 404.""" doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=5, uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27018") ) result = self.client.patch('/nonexistshard', data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 404) @ddt.data( {'name': u'\u6c49\u5b57\u6f22\u5b57'}, {'name': 'i'*65}, {'weight': -1} ) def test_insert_shard_bad_data(self, params): """Create shards with invalid names and weights. Assert 400.""" doc = helpers.create_shard_body( weight=params.get('weight', 10), uri=params.get('uri', "mongodb://127.0.0.1:27017") ) shard_name = params.get('name', "newshard") self.addCleanup(self.client.delete, url='/'+shard_name) result = self.client.put('/'+shard_name, data=doc) self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 400) def test_delete_shard_non_exist(self): """Delete a shard that doesn't exist. Assert 404.""" result = self.client.delete('/nonexistshard') self.assertEqual(result.status_code, 204)

subject: RecordSetNotFound over RPC
revisions:

commit_message:
RecordSetNotFound over RPC

Avoid throwing a trace when finding a single RecordSet
over RPC. Does not affect any exception handling as
the RPC client will still see the original exception.
Bug: #1304152

Change-Id: Ibcfda0fdc437fc1089a2d595281a3b0bef29b7f4

commit_message:
X.509 SSL certificate authentication plugin

Add a plugin for X.509 SSL certification authentication. This is similar to
Kerberos auth plugin. It must be used in conjunction with Apache mod_ssl.

DocImpact
SecurityImpact

Change-Id: I695e8deeb89826717ec859461ab2339d8af20805
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/36/103736/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from keystone.openstack.common import logLOG = log.getLogger(__name__) @dependency.requires('identity_api') class X509SSLCert(auth.AuthMethodHandler): """X.509 SSL client certificate authentication. This plugin is not domain-aware. This method must be used in conjunction with Apache mod_ssl. This also implies that Keystone must also be running in Apache mod_wsgi. In order for Apache mod_ssl to convey the SSL client certifciate information in the request environment, the `SSLOptions` directive must contains `+StdEnvVars` and the `SSLUserName` directive must set to a valid SSL requirement enviroment attribute. For example:: SSLOptions +StdEnvVars SSLUserName SSL_CLIENT_S_DN_CN .. note:: SSLUserName directive must not be used with +FakeBasicAuth option. For more details, please refer to `Apache mod_ssl <http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_ssl.html>`_ The auth method accepts the following configurations from the `[x509_ssl_cert_auth]` section in the Keystone configuration file. - `user_id_attribute` - the SSL client certificate attribute where Keystone user_id is conveyed. - `username_attribute` - the SSL client certificate attribute where Keystone username is conveyed. - `user_domain_id_attribute` - the SSL client certificate attribute where Keystone user domain ID is conveyed Will be ignored if plugin is not domain-aware. - `user_domain_name_attribute` - the SSL client certificate attribute where Keystone user domain name is conveyed. Will be ignored if plugin is not domain-aware. The Keystone identity must be established from the above attributes. """ method = 'x509' def _get_attribute(self, context, attribute_name): if attribute_name is not None: return context['environment'].get(attribute_name) def _get_domain_attributes(self, context): # use default domain ID as this plugin is not domain-aware return (CONF.identity.default_domain_id, None) def authenticate(self, context, auth_info, auth_context): user_id = self._get_attribute( context, CONF.x509_ssl_cert_auth.user_id_attribute) username = self._get_attribute( context, CONF.x509_ssl_cert_auth.username_attribute) (user_domain_id, user_domain_name) = self._get_domain_attributes( context) try: if user_id: user_ref = self.identity_api.get_user(user_id) elif username and (user_domain_id or user_domain_name): if user_domain_name and not user_domain_id: user_domain_id = self.identity_api.get_domain_by_name( user_domain_name)['id'] user_ref = self.identity_api.get_user_by_name(username, user_domain_id) auth_context['user_id'] = user_ref['id'] except (exception.UserNotFound, exception.DomainNotFound) as e: LOG.exception(e) raise exception.Unauthorized(e) class X509SSLCertDomain(X509SSLCert): """Domain-aware X.509 SSL client certificate authentication.""" def _get_domain_attributes(self, context): user_domain_id = self._get_attribute( context, CONF.x509_ssl_cert_auth.user_domain_id_attribute) user_domain_name = self._get_context( context, CONF.x509_ssl_cert_auth.user_domain_name_attribute) return (user_domain_id, user_domain_name)

commit_message:
Set path to config file in tempest

Fix critical bug in preparation for Tempest config generation:
when `TEMPEST_CONFIG_FILE` is not presented, variables `TEMPEST_CONFIG` and
`OS_TEST_PATH` are set wrong.

Change-Id: Ic3011e7268f9d7d989a29295a126b247ddc6df2c

commit_message:
Don't update neutron VIF if MAC is duplicated

Conductor Manager update_port() can be used to change the MAC address of
a Port. If the requested address already exists, a MACAlreadyExists
exception is raised and returned to the client. This patch changes two
aspects of that method:

* If a MACAlreadyExists exception is raised, it does not need to be
  logged by the conductor. This patch adds it to the list of expected
  exceptions to pass back over RPC.
* If the MAC is associated to a VIF in neutron, do not update that VIF
  if the new MAC duplicates another MAC already known to Ironic.

Change-Id: Ie5ff082c4656e81c268f93cd51d75799087fe0c9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/36/90436/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert "Split ExtraConfig into compute + control"

This commit needs to solicit more discussion and doesnt seem fully
thought through.

This reverts commit fbd8039ac978f67926faeadd4b0d6a4c4010705a.

Change-Id: I1b895de0c515c4406e185b6257c933d5070458c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/92/109092/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. heat $HEAT_OP -e $TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud-env.json \
deleted_lines: OVERCLOUD_COMPUTE_EXTRA_CONFIG=${OVERCLOUD_COMPUTE_EXTRA_CONFIG:-$OVERCLOUD_EXTRA_CONFIG} OVERCLOUD_CONTROL_EXTRA_CONFIG=${OVERCLOUD_CONTROL_EXTRA_CONFIG:-$OVERCLOUD_EXTRA_CONFIG}# NOTE: Temporary change to allow HEAT template patches to land. # Change-Id: Ieaee80e414130504a5e40e878a5a4ca1c196ca2b. if grep -q "Ref:\s*ExtraConfig" $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-heat-templates/overcloud.yaml; then # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. heat $HEAT_OP -e $TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud-env.json \else # create stack with a 6 hour timeout, and allow wait_for_stack_ready # to impose a realistic timeout. heat $HEAT_OP -e $TRIPLEO_ROOT/overcloud-env.json \ -t 360 \ -f $TRIPLEO_ROOT/tripleo-heat-templates/overcloud.yaml \ -P "NovaComputeExtraConfig=${OVERCLOUD_COMPUTE_EXTRA_CONFIG}" \ -P "ControllerExtraConfig=${OVERCLOUD_CONTROL_EXTRA_CONFIG}" \ $STACKNAME fi

commit_message:
Add a hp1 region configs.

These are internal to the deploy infrastructure, but we've discussed its
details in IRC already... may as well make it easy for admins to share
and evolve.

Change-Id: I864830950a6f3bab04b10cbe00dd539ea6f3fd5a

commit_message:
Fixed dhcp & gateway ip conflict in PLUMgrid plugin

   * Adjust dhcp IP if conflicts with gateway IP
   * Added unit test case

Closes-Bug:1333442

commit_message:
Don't expose X-Auth-Token in ceilometer CLI

Ceilometer CLI exposes X-Auth-Token in debug mode. This patch
replaces X-Auth-Token's value with '{SHA1}<sha1oftoken>'. Some
credentials are exposed by keystoneclient as ceilometerclient
uses keystoneclient to authenticate, it will be fixed in bug:
100414.

Change-Id: Ia6364314e4b4d26301f974582c0c2ba34b054c86
Partial-Bug: #1327019

commit_message:
Store volume backed snapshot in current tenant.

Fix owner of a creating volume backed snapshot.

Snapshot of an instance booted on a volume based on another tenant's
public image is created in the wrong tenant when invoked by admin.

Snapshot metadata (including owner) is based on image metadata. But
when the snapshot is being created by admin, Glance doesn't change
it's owner if it's set. So we forcibly remove owner (tenant)
attribute from image metadata.

Change-Id: I662dfa4f81e24cb2553ffa2578f4c8530eee9fd3
Closes-Bug: #1322195

commit_message:
Really ensure that sphinx <1.2 is installed

Because sphinx have release on pypi version suffixed by a letter for beta
purpose, ie: 1.2b3, even <1.2 is in requirement.txt 1.2b3 is installed.

This changes force the upper version to 1.1.999, to not install beta version
of sphinx 1.2.

Conflicts:
	global-requirements.txt

Change-Id: I951951ce24388cc1c7a9e472daf58a1e12124aba
Closes-bug: #1346827
(cherry picked from commit d79fb647a9800214caaa8679cf4030aa500c9f7a)

commit_message:
Removed use of BaseException.message from oslo.db

The usage of the .message attribute has been deprecated since Python 2.6.
However, the exceptions raised by SQLAlchemy can differ when using
unicode() and accessing .message. Using args[0] as a message is the best
we can do until SQLAlchemy is fully Python 3 compliant. SQLAlchemy itself
uses args[0] as a message internally.

Change-Id: I3b0edaba0604fa9885c145719287f236d7ba3fda
Closes-Bug: #1280435

commit_message:
Split ExtraConfig into compute + control

This allows specialisation of passthrough config between roles.

ExtraConfig has been left so that this patch can merge before the Heat changes
do. The next patch in this series removes ExtraConfig.

Change-Id: Ia90a62f4782b4c796578f098b6896e92715033ab

commit_message:
Add a Tunnel end-point variable for Neutron configuration

The HOST_IP address is being used as IP address
for end-point tunnel configruation. A new variable is
needed to specify a different IP address for the tunnel
end-point that Neutron will use

Change-Id: Ic7fb4853df167e78bf882af6a712b903db754dc2
Closes-bug: #1340433

commit_message:
Removed use of BaseException.message from oslo.db

The usage of the .message attribute has been deprecated since Python 2.6.
However, the exceptions raised by SQLAlchemy can differ when using
unicode() and accessing .message. Using args[0] as a message is the best
we can do until SQLAlchemy is fully Python 3 compliant. SQLAlchemy itself
uses args[0] as a message internally.

Change-Id: I1b98811c129e8fbd2a4f0c578473292d2c2d9717
Closes-Bug: #1280435

commit_message:
Big Switch: Remove consistency hash on full sync

Clears the consistency hash before performing a full
backend synchronization. Since all of the data is being
replaced, there is no reason to include this and it
currently requires special-casing to handle.

Closes-Bug: #1328233
Change-Id: Iace766d869dc78b041d3a5464e728b872c8347c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/63/98863/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The hash shouldn't be included during a topology sync because # we are replacing all of the data anyway self.consistency_hash = None

commit_message:
NSX: Remove unneed call to _ensure_default_security_group

This patch removes an unneeded call to _ensure_default_security_group
which does not need to be called in create_security_group_rule_bulk()
as one would need to call get_security_groups() to look up the uuid
of the default security group which be would created it for us, BOOM!

Change-Id: I628a94c7ea9553dcefa68fa956f25244f0abbb18
Closes-bug: 1340536
(cherry picked from commit e2dac9daf39d9b519df14441bbeb99c3c4a7bfaa)

commit_message:
Remove RST online editor as rst.ninjs.org is down

http://rst.ninjs.org URL is pointing to a domain name troller
possibly due to a miss in domain renewal.
Based on no good alternatives, it's OK to remove it and just
specify where to find the generated file.

Change-Id: I44a5c59b68fa08183b375b8b642c0e1fb389adaa

commit_message:
NSX: fix router ports port_security_enabled=False

Previously there was a bug that resulted in a security group being
added to router ports which was not supported in NSX. Removing the
security group didn't actually completely solve the problem as we
never cleared the allowed_address_pairs on the router port. This
patch fixes this issue by disabling port_security_enabled on the
router port.

Change-Id: Ib61756e3bd5866318cbc3bb9856344571399d656
Closes-bug: 1344266
Related-bug: 1329043
(cherry picked from commit 25f1439ff356f78ab0d28a74dfc75d50e2f030b6)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-02-06 15:22:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/710f0c5fddefb8172e524c65f17cc7f565f84033', 'message': 'Add extensible resources to resource tracker

A resource plug-in is added to the resource tracker to allow
the types of resources allocated at the compute node to be
extensible. Information maintained by these plug-ins is written
to the extra_resources field of the compute_nodes table in the
database. The scheduler reads the extra_resources data and can
use information to determine scheduling decisions.

This is part of: blueprint extensible-resource-tracking

Change-Id: I64108338e3c958ba1276aaf113a68861cbe286f5

commit_message:
Add extensible resources to resource tracker

A resource plugin extension point is added to the resource
tracker to allow the types of resources allocated at the compute
node to be extensible. Information maintained by these plug-ins
is written to the compute_nodes table in the database. The
scheduler uses the information in the compute_nodes table to
determine scheduling decisions.

A plugin that implements vcpu resource tracking is included
and all other code for tracking vcpu has been removed. This
example ensures the plugins are tested in gate jobs.

Co-Authored-By: Andrea Rosa  <andrea.rosa@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Paul Murray  <pmurray@hp.com>
This is part of: blueprint extensible-resource-tracking

Change-Id: I64108338e3c958ba1276aaf113a68861cbe286f5

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from nova import loadables class BaseResource(object): """Base class for all resource classes.""" def test_resource(self, extra_resources, instance_type, limits): """Test to see if we have sufficient resource to allocate to the instance considering the given limits. """ return True def update_from_instance(self, extra_resources, instance, instance_type): """Update resource information to reflect allocation of the given instance. """ pass class BaseResourceHandler(loadables.BaseLoader): """Base class to handle loading resource classes.""" def test_resources(self, resource_classes, extra_resources, instance_type, limits): """Each class is called to obtain resource state to reflect the effect of allocating this instance to this host. """ passes = True for resource_cls in resource_classes: resource = resource_cls() passes = passes and resource.test_resource(extra_resources, instance_type, limits) return passes def update_from_instance(self, resource_classes, extra_resources, instance, instance_type): """Update the resource information to reflect the allocation of the given instance. """ for resource_cls in resource_classes: resource = resource_cls() resource.update_from_instance(extra_resources, instance, instance_type)

subject: Move server task start delete into check_delete_complete
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-23 15:57:02.000000000', 'files': ['heat/engine/resources/server.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/b27d5a920d743ea479f17fd9f0480748415fa5b2', 'message': 'Move server task start delete into check_delete_complete

Starting the task in handle_delete has the undesirable side-effect of
serializing the delete calls to nova, which results in a noticeable
serialization of the resource deletes for non-dependent resources.

Moving the start to check_delete_complete solves the problem, then the
resources all transition into DELETE_IN_PROGRESS at approximately the
same time, and it can be observed that the underlying nova servers are
set into deleting state in parallel.

Change-Id: Ie59f0903b7aba1e40737bece049dd4b0c6cda233
Partial-Bug: #1347775
'}]
commit_message:
Move server task start delete into check_delete_complete

Starting the task in handle_delete has the undesirable side-effect of
serializing the delete calls to nova, which results in a noticeable
serialization of the resource deletes for non-dependent resources.

Moving the start to check_delete_complete solves the problem, then the
resources all transition into DELETE_IN_PROGRESS at approximately the
same time, and it can be observed that the underlying nova servers are
set into deleting state in parallel.

Change-Id: Ie59f0903b7aba1e40737bece049dd4b0c6cda233
Partial-Bug: #1347775
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/27/109027/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return scheduler.TaskRunner(nova_utils.delete_server, server) def check_delete_complete(self, delete_task): done = False if delete_task: if not delete_task.started(): delete_task.start() done = delete_task.done() else: done = delete_task.step() # The delete is either complete, or was never started (if the # server.get raised NotFound) if done or delete_task is None:
deleted_lines: deleter = scheduler.TaskRunner(nova_utils.delete_server, server) deleter.start() return deleter def check_delete_complete(self, deleter): if deleter is None or deleter.step():

commit_message:
Add RPC call to retrieve the parameters for a stack

Given a stack id, load the stack from the DB and return the
parameters and registry currently used.  These are from the
last stack-create or stack-update command and were combined
from the --parameters CLI and the environment file.

Partially-implements: blueprint troubleshooting-low-level-control
Closes-Bug: 1224828
Change-Id: Ie78dcde79518ac8598641c26366992e4ea4241f6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/24/107524/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_parameters(self, cnxt, stack_identity): """ Get the environment and parameters. :param cnxt: RPC context. :param stack_identity: Name of the stack you want to see. """ s = self._get_stack(cnxt, stack_identity, show_deleted=True) if s: return s.parameters return None @request_context

commit_message:
Test script for CRUD operations on trove instances

Adds a directory instances with test script 'test_instances.py' to
database api tests.
Adds related JSON supporting methods in client file
'instance_client.py' present in 'tempest/services/database/json'.
Adds api_schema for database instances in 'tempest/api_schema'
directory.
Addition of api_schema includes creation of a folder for database with
two files 'instances.py' and 'parameter_types.py'.
Modified 'tempest.conf.sample' and 'config.py' to add parameters
build_interval and build_timeout.
Modified 'base.py' of api database tests and clients.py to add the
details of instance_client.py.
Adds a method 'wait_for_db_instance_status' to waiters.py present in
'tempest/common' so as to implement logic to wait till db instance
reaches the desired status.

Change-Id: I0360dc4d7dc7eb8ac07498bca7289b93cf37c0f1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/05/108605/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
generic-mapping-federation

Proposal to reengineer federation to ensure that the process for authentication
using a federated source is standardized for all protocols and that a user_id
is always returned with the extracted assertion data.

Change-Id: Iad52e40b80eb6b6fc7071b8ee1fe5b3d363da866
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/01/104301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================================== Re-engineering Federation to standardize mapping and token creation =================================================================== `bp reengineered-federation <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/example>`_ We propose that the federated authentication process be reengineered so that requests for authentication are subject to a standardized process consisting of both protocol dependent and independent stages. Problem Description =================== Currently, the federation code uses saml2 specific modules for token creation and for managing the mapping and attribute extraction of external authentication data. While this is sufficient for the current release where only saml2 is supported as an authentication protocol, the upcoming changes for adding keystone-to-keystone federation as well as any further additions mean that processing other protocols will involve rewriting the logic for these operations. Proposed Change =============== We propose that the federation process be reengineered to allow standardization of authentication / authorization processes for all protocols In order to achieve this, incoming authentication requests from federated sources should following a common flow, using the same protocol independent modules to manage any common functions, and delegating any protocol dependent logic to protocol specific modules. We assume that every protocol will have its own protocol specific handling module in Keystone. In the case of an Apache plugin doing the protocol handling, then every plugin will potentially have its own protocol handling module (the exception would be if two Apache plugins communicate attributes in exactly the same way) The flow should be as follows: * The federation module should receive requests to the federation endpoint (OS-FEDERATION/identity_provider/{idp_id}/protocol/{protocol_id}/auth). * The data should be passed to the appropriate protocol module based on the specified protocol_id. The data should be processed according to the needs of the protocol and the following data extracted: * unique user ID (user_id) * authenticating IdP (idp_id) * list of dictionaries containing: * user identity attributes (list of key / value pairs) * IdP that issued them * When the extracted and formatted data is returned, the attributes should be filtered to remove any untrusted attributes using the proposed trusted attribute policy: `trusted_attribute_policy spec <https://review.openstack.org/#/c/100279/>`_ * Any remaining attributes should then be passed into the mapping engine and the resulting mapped groups and attributes should be returned. * This data should be passed the token creation module (currently called saml2 but should be renamed federated token creation). * Optionally, it should be allowed for deployments to choose to package the original attribute assertions in the final token alongside the mapped groups and attributes. Those implimentation concerned about token size would only hold the mapped data, those that want full provenance information would add the mapped data to the list of identity attributes/IdP issuer Alternatives ------------ Alternatively, each protocol added to Keystone could manage the mapping and token creation operations independently, however, any changes to the these interfaces would then have a large impact on federation. Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- As this spec involves changing the process by which tokens are produced, this could impact security. If the optional case of adding the original attribute assertions is enabled then extra user data is being exposed to any services which consume these tokens. Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- This will not affect existing client operation, but ideally, clients should be updated to work with any avilable protocols. Performance Impact ------------------ This should not affect performance. Developer Impact ---------------- This would force developers to implement new federated protocols in a standardized way by requiring the return values of protocol modules to take the same form. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: None Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Reengineer the current federation process Dependencies ============ None but would complement the trusted attribute policy spec. Testing ======= Current federation tests should still provide coverage. Documentation Impact ==================== Development docs should specify the return structure for new protocols but end user experience should not change. Subsequent implementations should be easier as only protocol specific code should need to be added. References ========== None

commit_message:
Order execution of environment.d scripts

In case there are dependencies between scripts, IE one script defines an
env var another relies on.

This change should be in line with current expectations, given the
convention is to numerically prefix scripts in this directory.

Change-Id: Icc509f695d7a15a8026d8c7e463f06acf65499d7

commit_message:
Update devstack endpoint creation to include v1

Currently with v1 missing, the barbican client doesn't include the /v1
part of the endpoint and gets 404's for all requests.

Change-Id: I14e6083084e4c05998dea2cacb5ac921c340d059

commit_message:
parse the mysql cnf file for password

This is a lighter way of getting the password rather than shelling out
to awk the file. This way the user the guestagent is running as does not
require access to awk.

Change-Id: Id8b74604099e6e941ea6e133d25fe4d44eed8e83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/07/104107/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: user_name = None password = None with open(MYSQL_CONFIG, 'r') as f: is_in_client = False lines = f.readlines() for line in lines: print(line) if "[client]" in line: is_in_client = True elif is_in_client: m = re.match("^(\\w+)\\s*=\\s*['\"]?(.[^'\"]*)['\"]?\\s*$", line) if m and m.group(2): if "user" == m.group(1): user_name = m.group(2) elif "password" == m.group(1): password = m.group(2) if user_name and password: return password.strip()
deleted_lines: pwd, err = utils.execute_with_timeout( "sudo", "awk", "/password\\t=/{print $3; exit}", MYSQL_CONFIG) if err: LOG.error(err) raise RuntimeError("Problem reading my.cnf! : %s" % err) return pwd.strip()

commit_message:
Exclude Routes 2.0

The py33 wheel published on PyPI for Routes is broken, and as a
result causes failures for our Py3k unit test jobs when it's a
project requirement. https://github.com/bbangert/routes/issues/31

Conflicts:
	global-requirements.txt

Change-Id: I66fe7a29362c45bc6af8b473f14433656e14d3d0
(cherry picked from commit 80366feb60fe3501c8c003efbd6905a1bc111b6e)

subject: Add partial specs support in ML2 for multiprovider extension
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-06-20 10:03:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8fef0ceff57e47e959ff4db88b339b6bef7485e0', 'message': 'Add partial specs support in ML2 for multiprovider extension

ML2 provider network partial specs let admins choose some
multiprovider network attributes and let neutron choose remaining
attributes. This change provides the implementation for
multiprovider networks.

In practice, for VLAN/GRE/VXLAN segments provider:segmentation_id
choice can be delegated to neutron, in such case neutron try to find
a segment in tenant network pools which respects provided segment
attributes. For VLAN segments provider:physical_network choice can
also be delegated.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint provider-network-partial-specs

Change-Id: I1cf1441a179ec527674276b71e9924841f8570b6
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-06-23 13:36:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/0f283d86356426605d3a4dc0c8d8177a3e2e9a86', 'message': 'Add partial specs support in ML2 for multiprovider extension

ML2 provider network partial specs let admins choose some
multiprovider network attributes and let neutron choose remaining
attributes. This change provides the implementation for
multiprovider networks.

In practice, for VLAN/GRE/VXLAN segments provider:segmentation_id
choice can be delegated to neutron, in such case neutron try to find
a segment in tenant network pools which respects provided segment
attributes. For VLAN segments provider:physical_network choice can
also be delegated.

DocImpact

commit_message:
Add partial specs support in ML2 for multiprovider extension

ML2 provider network partial specs let admins choose some
multiprovider network attributes and let neutron choose remaining
attributes. This change provides the implementation for
multiprovider networks.

In practice, for VLAN/GRE/VXLAN segments provider:segmentation_id
choice can be delegated to neutron, in such case neutron try to find
a segment in tenant network pools which respects provided segment
attributes. For VLAN segments provider:physical_network choice can
also be delegated.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint provider-network-partial-specs

Change-Id: I1cf1441a179ec527674276b71e9924841f8570b6
