commit_message:
Added trove config group section

The trove chapter in the user guide did not have
a section on how to use configuration groups.

This commit covers how to use config groups
to configure database parameters.

This commit completes the implementation of the
blueprint.

Edits for consistency - df

Change-Id: I749e7a1b0d2bfac799555844a15a99b24b46b7a2
blueprint: user-guide-trove-chapter
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/16/107816/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Manage database configuration You can manage database configuration tasks by using configuration groups. Configuration groups let you set configuration parameters, in bulk, on one or more databases. This example assumes you have created a MySQL database and shows you how to use a configuration group to configure it. To configure a database using a configuration group First, determine which configuration parameters you can set. There are different available parameters for different datastore versions. Start by listing the names and IDs of all available versions of the mysql datastore: $ trove datastore-version-list mysql +--------------------------------------+-----------+ | id | name | +--------------------------------------+-----------+ | eeb574ce-f49a-48b6-820d-b2959fcd38bb | mysql-5.5 | +--------------------------------------+-----------+ Pass in the datastore version ID with the trove configuration-parameter-list command to get the available parameters: $ trove configuration-parameter-list DATASTORE_VERSION_ID +--------------------------------+---------+---------+----------------------+------------------+ | name | type | min | max | restart_required | +--------------------------------+---------+---------+----------------------+------------------+ | auto_increment_increment | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | auto_increment_offset | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | autocommit | integer | 0 | 1 | False | | bulk_insert_buffer_size | integer | 0 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | character_set_client | string | | | False | | character_set_connection | string | | | False | | character_set_database | string | | | False | | character_set_filesystem | string | | | False | | character_set_results | string | | | False | | character_set_server | string | | | False | | collation_connection | string | | | False | | collation_database | string | | | False | | collation_server | string | | | False | | connect_timeout | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | expire_logs_days | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | innodb_buffer_pool_size | integer | 0 | 68719476736 | True | | innodb_file_per_table | integer | 0 | 1 | True | | innodb_flush_log_at_trx_commit | integer | 0 | 2 | False | | innodb_log_buffer_size | integer | 1048576 | 4294967296 | True | | innodb_open_files | integer | 10 | 4294967296 | True | | innodb_thread_concurrency | integer | 0 | 1000 | False | | interactive_timeout | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | join_buffer_size | integer | 0 | 4294967296 | False | | key_buffer_size | integer | 0 | 4294967296 | False | | local_infile | integer | 0 | 1 | False | | max_allowed_packet | integer | 1024 | 1073741824 | False | | max_connect_errors | integer | 1 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | max_connections | integer | 1 | 65535 | False | | max_user_connections | integer | 1 | 100000 | False | | myisam_sort_buffer_size | integer | 4 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | server_id | integer | 1 | 100000 | True | | sort_buffer_size | integer | 32768 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | sync_binlog | integer | 0 | 18446744073709547520 | False | | wait_timeout | integer | 1 | 31536000 | False | +--------------------------------+---------+---------+----------------------+------------------+ In this example, the configuration-parameter-list command returns a list of parameters that work with MySQL 5.5. Create a configuration group. A configuration group contains a comma-separated list of key-value pairs. Each pair consists of a configuration parameter you want to set and the value you want to set it to. You can create a configuration group by using the trove configuration-create command. The general syntax for this command is trove configuration-create NAME VALUES --datastore DATASTORE_NAME. NAME is the name you want to use for this group, VALUES is the list of key-value pairs, and DATASTORE_NAME is the name of the associated datastore. You set VALUES as a JSON dictionary, for example: {"myFirstKey" : "someString", "mySecondKey" : someInt} This example creates a configuration group called group1. group1 contains just one key-value pair, and this pair sets the sync_binlog parameter to 1. $ trove configuration-create group1 '{"sync_binlog" : 1}' --datastore mysql +----------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +----------------------+--------------------------------------+ | datastore_version_id | eeb574ce-f49a-48b6-820d-b2959fcd38bb | | description | None | | id | 9a9ef3bc-079b-476a-9cbf-85aa64f898a5 | | name | group1 | | values | {"sync_binlog": 1} | +----------------------+--------------------------------------+ Examine your existing configuration. Before using the newly-created configuration group, take a look at the how the sync_binlog parameter is currently configured on your database. Replace the sample connection values below with values that connect you to your database: $ mysql -u user7 -ppassword -h 172.16.200.2 myDB7 Welcome to the MySQL monitor. Commands end with ; or \g. Your MySQL connection id is 81 Server version: 5.5.37-0ubuntu0.14.04.1 (Ubuntu) Copyright (c) 2000, 2014, Oracle and/or its affiliates. All rights reserved. Oracle is a registered trademark of Oracle Corporation and/or its affiliates. Other names may be trademarks of their respective owners. Type 'help;' or '\h' for help. Type '\c' to clear the current input statement. mysql> mysql> show variables like 'sync_binlog'; +---------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +---------------+-------+ | sync_binlog | 0 | +---------------+-------+ As you can see, sync_binlog is currently set to 0 for the database called myDB7. Change the database configuration using a configuration group. You can change a database's configuration by attaching a configuration group to a database instance. You do this by using the trove configuration-attach command and passing in the ID of the configuration group and the ID of the database instance. Get the ID of the configuration group: $ trove configuration-list +--------------------------------------+--------+-------------+--------------------------------------+ | id | name | description | datastore_version_id | +--------------------------------------+--------+-------------+--------------------------------------+ | 9a9ef3bc-079b-476a-9cbf-85aa64f898a5 | group1 | None | eeb574ce-f49a-48b6-820d-b2959fcd38bb | +--------------------------------------+--------+-------------+--------------------------------------+ Get the ID of the database instance: $ trove list +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ | id | name | datastore | datastore_version | status | flavor_id | size | +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ | 26a265dd-1c88-4333-b3ed-6b4e9e87ffbb | mysql_instance_7 | mysql | mysql-5.5 | ACTIVE | 6 | 5 | +--------------------------------------+------------------+-----------+-------------------+--------+-----------+------+ Attach the configuration group to the database instance: $ trove configuration-attach CONFIG_GROUP_ID DB_INSTANCE_ID Re-examine the database configuration. Display the sync_binlog setting again: mysql> show variables like 'sync_binlog'; +---------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +---------------+-------+ | sync_binlog | 1 | +---------------+-------+ As you can see, sync_binlog is now set to 1, as specified in the group1 configuration group. Conclusion. Using a configuration group to set a single parameter on a single database is obviously a trivial example. However, configuration groups can provide major efficiencies when you consider that: A configuration group can specify a large number of parameter values. You can apply a configuration group to hundreds or thousands of database instances in your environment. Used in this way, configuration groups let you modify your database cloud configuration, on the fly, on a massive scale. Maintenance. There are also a number of useful maintenancce features for working with configuration groups. You can: Disassociate a configuration group from a database instance using the trove configuration-detach command. Modify a configuration group on the fly, using the trove configuration-patch command. Find out what instances are using a configuration group, using the trove configuration-instances command. Delete a configuration group, using the trove configuration-delete command. You may want to do this if no instances are using a group.

subject: Fix compatibility with tempest project
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-23 05:54:04.000000000', 'files': ['contrib/tempest/tempest/cli/simple_read_only/test_manila.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/2a0890e3580f0cf1e7578c1f59eef55431ef0c65', 'message': 'Fix compatibility with tempest project

commit_message:
Fix compatibility with tempest project

Cli tempest test that tests answer for nonexistent
command fails due to change in tempest, see:
https://github.com/openstack/tempest/commit/7a2cf01f8b629c5b40def151780ddadb6d9d3416

Made same changes for manila test.

Change-Id: Ic863c1f232f17b04a8a914ee01dc14e84a458806

commit_message:
Changes to use monasca instead of mon

Added monasca_common to beginning of sub projects so they will be
published

Also added copy of created jars to target directory so they will
be published

Change-Id: I8b73754947b18183ef1e1e13d9b340dff69ca24c

commit_message:
Rename saml2_token_url to token_url

For the consisteny a property returning authentication url
should be called token_url.
This patch renames ``saml2_token_url`` to ``token_url`` in the
contrib.auth.v3.saml2.Saml2UnscopedPlugin plugin.

Change-Id: I435a118bb31338a37a29eec68b8e9ce50d163675

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-23 10:18:03.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/contrib/auth/v3/saml2.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/bad4bf928d57806033d53bab1e7cc766b0d8eef0', 'message': 'Enforce authenticated=False in saml2 plugin

All underlying HTTP calls executed via ``keystoneclient.session.Session``
object should have ``authenticated=False`` option enforced indicating the

Change-Id: I946f1ed6a55c4172d8f4bf6a24e5cbc3a00d1154
'}]
commit_message:
Enforce authenticated=False in saml2 plugin

All underlying HTTP calls executed via ``keystoneclient.session.Session``
object should have ``authenticated=False`` option enforced indicating the
plugin is not authenticated with the Identity Service yet.

Change-Id: I946f1ed6a55c4172d8f4bf6a24e5cbc3a00d1154
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/44/108944/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return session.request(location, method, authenticated=False, **kwargs) requests_auth=(self.username, self.password), authenticated=False)

commit_message:
Add host argument to get_connect_string()

'localhost' value used to be hardcoded in get_connect_string().
Now it's possible to pass a custom host name as a function argument.
Wrote test for this

Change-Id: I3ae9f1a7df0bb378da1210cd89eef3e5f203cf34

deleted_lines: def get_connect_string(backend, database, user=None, passwd=None): template = "%(backend)s://%(user)s:%(passwd)s@localhost/%(database)s"

commit_message:
Make MySQL regexes generic across MySQL drivers

Note that mysqlconnector raises InternalError whereas mysqldb raises
OperationalError when a deadlock is found.  The reported error codes and
messages are identical, however.

Change-Id: Iac9167e0777e0bf4361bcf6a8722923cce052b90

subject: Remove output filter on rabbitmq install
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-23 04:27:07.000000000', 'files': ['lib/rpc_backend'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/7ccf4e025a3bcb90b4fe419b232742a67746872b', 'message': "Remove output filter on rabbitmq install

The original workaround was for an init script that grabbed stdout.
This was some time ago and I think it's safe to remove.

It can be a problem on Fedora; out-of-the-box some old F20 images can
have a broken dependency when rabbitmq installs.  With this in place,
all helpful output goes into the temp log file, but it is never shown
because the install_packages function exits the script.  Thus things
just stop and you have no idea why.

Change-Id: I2f5b934492a8c9d7b93e89fdcfa776bf15f25cb8
"}]
commit_message:
Remove output filter on rabbitmq install

The original workaround was for an init script that grabbed stdout.
This was some time ago and I think it's safe to remove.

It can be a problem on Fedora; out-of-the-box some old F20 images can
have a broken dependency when rabbitmq installs.  With this in place,
all helpful output goes into the temp log file, but it is never shown
because the install_packages function exits the script.  Thus things
just stop and you have no idea why.

Change-Id: I2f5b934492a8c9d7b93e89fdcfa776bf15f25cb8

added_lines: ================================================================================ NetScaler LBaaS V2 Driver ================================================================================ NetScaler ADC driver for LBaaS v2 model https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/netscaler-lbaas-driver Problem description =================== Driver for the Neutron LBaaS plugin for using the Citrix NetScaler loadbalancing devices to provide Neutron LBaaS functionality in OpenStack based on the LBaaS V2 model described in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89903/. Proposed change =============== The driver will implement the interfaces according to the driver interfaces mentioned in the spec https://review.openstack.org/100690 for the blueprint https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/lbaas-objmodel-driver-changes The following managers will be implemented: * LoadBalancerManager * ListenerManager * PoolManager * MemberManager * HealthMonitorManager Alternatives ------------ None. Data model impact ----------------- None. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: https://launchpad.net/~vijay-venkatachalam Work Items ---------- * NetScaler driver code * Unit tests * Voting CI Dependencies ============ * https://review.openstack.org/#/c/101084/ Testing ======= * Unit tests * NetScaler QA. * Existing NetScaler CI will be enhanced to test LBaaS V2 model with NetScaler as the backend Documentation Impact ==================== None. References ========== None.

Create file with all scenarios for use from CI

* Add scenarios from: Keystone, Nova, Glance, Cinder, Ceilometer, Heat
* Add scenarios for Authentication and Quotas
* All scenarios are configured with high levels of concurrency

commit_message:
Really ensure that sphinx <1.2 is installed

Because sphinx have release on pypi version suffixed by a letter for beta
purpose, ie: 1.2b3, even <1.2 is in requirement.txt 1.2b3 is installed.

This changes force the upper version to 1.1.999, to not install beta version
of sphinx 1.2.

Change-Id: I951951ce24388cc1c7a9e472daf58a1e12124aba
Closes-bug: #1346827

commit_message:
swift: remove compression

This was necessary back when using the first driver version using
Whisper instead of Carbonara, but this is not needed anymore and will
reduce latency.

Change-Id: I8ae7a27298636ca9e0504a316c48d8f2c930565f

commit_message:
Explicitly states the keystonemiddleware version

Currently, there is no version listed. However, there exists a page for
version 0 of the library in pypi.

https://pypi.python.org/pypi/keystonemiddleware/0

This change states the version of the library to "greater than equal"
1.0.0 which is the first real version of the same.

Change-Id: I2bbee6db56e166387d34a4655996a85db9b64ad3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/67/107467/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Set top version for python-keystoneclient

Required to ensure that no system level dependencies will be
added to keystoneclient, which can break our ci

Related-Bug: #1347583
Change-Id: I1baed0598ae730f5a2a14b8dc9cd331aea37d34c

commit_message:
carbonara: change time serie aggregation implementation

Following recent discussions, this uses a new scheme to implement the
timeserie aggregation in Carbonara.
We use a infinite-precision timeserie in TimeSerieArchive that is used
to compute the aggregation of all the archived timeseries.

Change-Id: I346ba5b316049ba622c8f6e633cf9aaea1c0519c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/85/105185/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class NoDeloreanAvailable(Exception): """Error raised when trying to insert a value that is too old.""" def __init__(self, timestamps=None, values=None): return self.ts.all() == other.ts.all() def get(self, key): return self.ts[key] def set_values(self, values): for timestamp, value in values: self.ts[timestamp] = value return cls(values, timestamps) def to_dict(self): return { 'values': dict((six.text_type(k), float(v)) for k, v in six.iteritems(self.ts[~self.ts.isnull()])), } def serialize(self): return msgpack.dumps(self.to_dict()) @classmethod def unserialize(cls, data): return cls.from_dict(msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')) class BoundTimeSerie(TimeSerie): def __init__(self, timestamps=None, values=None, timespan=None): super(BoundTimeSerie, self).__init__(timestamps, values) self.timespan = pandas.tseries.frequencies.to_offset(timespan) self._truncate() def __eq__(self, other): return (super(BoundTimeSerie, self).__eq__(other) and self.timespan == other.timespan) def set_values(self, values, before_truncate_callback=None): if self.timespan is not None and len(self.ts): # Check that the smallest timestamp does not go too much back in # time. # TODO(jd) convert keys to timestamp to be sure we can subtract? if (min(map(operator.itemgetter(0), values)) < (self.ts.index[-1] - self.timespan)): raise NoDeloreanAvailable super(BoundTimeSerie, self).set_values(values) if before_truncate_callback: before_truncate_callback(self) self._truncate() @classmethod def from_dict(cls, d): """Build a time series from a dict. The dict format must be datetime as key and values as values. :param d: The dict. :returns: A TimeSerie object """ values_and_timestamps = tuple( zip(*dict( (pandas.Timestamp(k), v) for k, v in six.iteritems(d['values'])).items())) if values_and_timestamps: values, timestamps = values_and_timestamps else: values, timestamps = (), () return cls(values, timestamps, timespan=d.get('timespan')) def to_dict(self): basic = super(BoundTimeSerie, self).to_dict() basic.update({ 'timespan': self._serialize_time_period(self.timespan), }) return basic def _truncate(self): """Truncate the timeserie.""" if self.timespan: for timestamp, value in self.ts.iteritems(): if timestamp >= (self.ts.index[-1] - self.timespan): self.ts = self.ts[timestamp:] break class AggregatedTimeSerie(TimeSerie): def __init__(self, timestamps=None, values=None, max_size=None, block_size=None, sampling=None, aggregation_method='mean'): super(AggregatedTimeSerie, self).__init__(timestamps, values) self.aggregation_method = aggregation_method self.sampling = pandas.tseries.frequencies.to_offset(sampling) self.max_size = max_size self.block_size = pandas.tseries.frequencies.to_offset(block_size) self._resample() self._truncate() def __eq__(self, other): return (self.ts.all() == other.ts.all() and self.max_size == other.max_size and self.block_size == other.block_size and self.sampling == other.sampling and self.aggregation_method == other.aggregation_method) def set_values(self, values): super(AggregatedTimeSerie, self).set_values(values) self._truncate() @classmethod def from_dict(cls, d): """Build a time series from a dict. The dict format must be datetime as key and values as values. :param d: The dict. :returns: A TimeSerie object """ values_and_timestamps = tuple( zip(*dict( (pandas.Timestamp(k), v) for k, v in six.iteritems(d['values'])).items())) if values_and_timestamps: values, timestamps = values_and_timestamps else: values, timestamps = (), () return cls(values, timestamps, max_size=d.get('max_size'), sampling=d.get('sampling'), block_size=d.get('block_size'), aggregation_method=d.get('aggregation_method', 'mean')) def to_dict(self): d = super(AggregatedTimeSerie, self).to_dict() d.update({ }) return d for timestamp, value in self.ts.iteritems(): if timestamp >= first_point: self.ts = self.ts[timestamp:] break else: # Clear it all! self.ts = self.ts[0:0] # NOTE(jd) Is there a more efficient way to do that with Pandas? The # goal is to delete all the values that `ts' is providing again, so # that means deleting the aggregate we did for it too. for timestamp, value in self.ts.iteritems(): if timestamp >= ts.ts.index[0] or timestamp <= ts.ts.index[-1]: del self.ts[timestamp] class TimeSerieArchive(object): def __init__(self, timeserie, agg_timeseries): self.timeserie = timeserie self.agg_timeseries = agg_timeseries def from_definitions(cls, definitions, aggregation_method='mean'): """Create a new collection of archived time series. :param definition: A list of tuple (sampling, max_size) """ definitions = sorted(definitions, key=operator.itemgetter(0)) # The block size is the coarse grained archive definition block_size = definitions[-1][0] # Limit the main timeserie to a timespan mapping return cls(BoundTimeSerie(timespan=block_size), [ AggregatedTimeSerie( max_size=size, sampling=sampling, block_size=block_size, aggregation_method=aggregation_method) for sampling, size in definitions ]) for ts in self.agg_timeseries: return (self.timeserie == other.timeserie and self.agg_timeseries == other.agg_timeseries) def _update_aggregated_timeseries(self, timeserie): for agg in self.agg_timeseries: agg.update(timeserie) def set_values(self, values): # FIXME(jd) Why convert here and not in all TimeSerie types? # timestamp = pandas.Timestamp(timestamp, unit='s') self.timeserie.set_values( values, before_truncate_callback=self._update_aggregated_timeseries) def to_dict(self): return { "timeserie": self.timeserie.to_dict(), "archives": [ts.to_dict() for ts in self.agg_timeseries], } @classmethod def from_dict(cls, d): return cls(BoundTimeSerie.from_dict(d['timeserie']), [AggregatedTimeSerie.from_dict(a) for a in d['archives']]) return cls.from_dict(msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')) def serialize(self): return msgpack.dumps(self.to_dict())
deleted_lines: import itertools def __init__(self, timestamps, values, block_size=None, max_size=None, sampling=None, aggregation_method='mean'): self.aggregation_method = aggregation_method self.sampling = pandas.tseries.frequencies.to_offset(sampling) self.max_size = max_size self.block_size = pandas.tseries.frequencies.to_offset(block_size) self._resample() self._truncate() return (self.ts.all() == other.ts.all() and self.max_size == other.max_size and self.block_size == other.block_size and self.sampling == other.sampling and self.aggregation_method == other.aggregation_method) def __setitem__(self, key, value): self.ts[key] = value self._truncate() return cls(values, timestamps, max_size=d.get('max_size'), block_size=d.get('block_size'), sampling=d.get('sampling'), aggregation_method=d.get('aggregation_method', 'mean')) def to_dict(self): return { 'values': dict((six.text_type(k), float(v)) for k, v in six.iteritems(self.ts[~self.ts.isnull()])), } self.ts = self.ts[first_point:] def serialize(self): return msgpack.dumps(self.to_dict()) def unserialize(cls, data): return cls.from_dict(msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')) class TimeSerieCollection(object): def __init__(self, timeseries): if timeseries: agg = timeseries[0].aggregation_method for ts in timeseries[1:]: if ts.aggregation_method != agg: raise ValueError( "All time series must use the same aggregation method") self.timeseries = sorted(timeseries, key=operator.attrgetter('sampling')) # Check that (ts1, ts2) are multiple, then (ts2, ts3), etc. for ts1, ts2 in itertools.izip(self.timeseries, self.timeseries[1:]): if ts2.sampling.nanos % ts1.sampling.nanos != 0: raise ValueError( "Timeserie %s and timeserie %s sampling periods" " are not multiple (%dns and %dns)" % (ts1, ts2, ts1.sampling.nanos, ts2.sampling.nanos)) for ts in self.timeseries: return self.timeseries == other.timeseries def serialize(self): return msgpack.dumps([ts.to_dict() for ts in self.timeseries]) def __setitem__(self, timestamp, value): timestamp = pandas.Timestamp(timestamp, unit='s') for ts in self.timeseries: ts[timestamp] = value def __getitem__(self, key): if isinstance(key, slice): if key.step: raise ValueError("Unable to use step on getitem %s", self.__class__.__name__) return self.fetch(key.start, key.stop) return self.fetch(key) return cls([TimeSerie.from_dict(ts) for ts in msgpack.loads(data, encoding='utf-8')])

commit_message:
Initial cirros element

Creates a cirros image ready to be booted in openstack.
It can receive a specific cirros version via DIB_CIRRROS_RELEASE
environment variable, accepting also the value 'latest' for newest
release.

Change-Id: Ic6baa3366b6d148829e0b6f9c6d2e411fdde4072
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/64/94664/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # These are useful, or at worst not harmful, for all images we build. set -eux set -o pipefail [ -n "$ARCH" ] [ -n "$TARGET_ROOT" ] shopt -s extglob DIB_CIRROS_MIRROR=${DIB_CIRROS_MIRROR:-http://download.cirros-cloud.net} DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE=${DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE:-0.3.2} BASE_IMAGE_FILE=cirros-${DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE}-${ARCH/amd64/x86_64}-disk.img CACHED_FILE=$DIB_IMAGE_CACHE/$BASE_IMAGE_FILE if [ -n "$DIB_OFFLINE" -a -f "$CACHED_FILE" ] ; then echo "Not checking freshness of cached $CACHED_FILE." else echo "Fetching Base Image" if [ "${DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE}" == "latest" ]; then DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE=$($TMP_HOOKS_PATH/bin/cache-url $DIB_CIRROS_MIRROR/version/released >(cat) 1>&2) BASE_IMAGE_FILE=cirros-${DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE}-${ARCH/amd64/x86_64}-disk.img CACHED_FILE=$DIB_IMAGE_CACHE/$BASE_IMAGE_FILE fi echo $BASE_IMAGE_FILE MD5SUM=$($TMP_HOOKS_PATH/bin/cache-url ${DIB_CIRROS_MIRROR}/${DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE}/MD5SUMS >(cat) 1>&2 | awk '/'$BASE_IMAGE_FILE'/ {print $1}') $TMP_HOOKS_PATH/bin/cache-url ${DIB_CIRROS_MIRROR}/${DIB_CIRROS_RELEASE}/${BASE_IMAGE_FILE} $CACHED_FILE pushd $DIB_IMAGE_CACHE echo "$MD5SUM $BASE_IMAGE_FILE" | md5sum --check - popd fi source $_LIB/img-defaults source $_LIB/common-functions source $_LIB/img-functions ensure_nbd tmp_file=$(mktemp) trap "rm -f $tmp_file" EXIT cp $CACHED_FILE $tmp_file mount_qcow_image $tmp_file sudo cp -a $WORK_DIR/* $TARGET_ROOT if [ -e "$TARGET_ROOT/lost+found" ]; then sudo rmdir $TARGET_ROOT/lost+found fi unmount_qcow_image

commit_message:
Hardcode the logging level in swift_middleware

Now Swift writes it's proxy-server-logs into syslog as well as swift-proxy.log.
This behaviour is to be changed after adding oslo.logging into Swift.
From the other hand, we use pipeline.setup_pipeline inside Swift. And all swift-logging configs
become applied to Ceilometer's pipeline. As a result (in case of DEBUG is on) we see too many
Ceilometr-related messages in syslog.

This fix partially closes the bug below.

Closes bug 1294789

Change-Id: Ibec7ef8ca763e577235077a086f002f9683d5296

commit_message:
Allow capabilities to be set on ironic nodes

Since Ide39f4a2796b169025bf0083e021166ae35f30f8, Ironic has been able to
pass nodes' capabilities to the nova scheduler to allow for more
flexible and precise scheduling of instances.  This patch allows devtest
to pass capabilities from nodes.json (if they are present) to the
'ironic node-update' command which is already used to set nodes'
cpu_arch, memory and disk.

Part of bp targeted-node-deployment

Change-Id: I533336d193ee7bc46a7be79ff689f447aaf5770a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/08/107308/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Common properties and capabilities. properties=$(jq -r '"properties/cpus=" + (.cpu|tostring) + " properties/memory_mb=" + (.memory|tostring) + " properties/local_gb=" + (.disk|tostring) + " properties/cpu_arch=" + .arch' <<< $NODE_JSON) capabilities=$(jq -r 'if .capabilities then "properties/capabilities=" + .capabilities else empty end' <<< $NODE_JSON) ironic node-update $NODE_ID add ${properties} ${capabilities}
deleted_lines: # Common properties. ironic node-update $NODE_ID add $(jq -r '"properties/cpus=" + (.cpu|tostring) + " properties/memory_mb=" + (.memory|tostring) + " properties/local_gb=" + (.disk|tostring) + " properties/cpu_arch=" + .arch' <<< $NODE_JSON)

commit_message:
Add drivers.base.BaseDriver.get_properties()

Adds ironic.drivers.base.BaseDriver.get_properties() which returns a
dictionary of <property>:<description> entries.

The driver interfaces (DeployInterface, PowerInterface, ...) have a
new get_properties() method that returns a dictionary of
<property>:<description>.

These changes are needed in order to provide an API to get driver_info
properties.

Change-Id: I5994e990deb26841633ca26de1a5fb63b743271a
Blueprint: get-required-driver-info
Partial-Bug: #1261915

added_lines: def get_properties(self): return {} def get_properties(self): return {} def get_properties(self): return {'A1': 'A1 description. Required.', 'A2': 'A2 description. Optional.'} def get_properties(self): return {'B1': 'B1 description. Required.', 'B2': 'B2 description. Required.'} def get_properties(self): return {} def get_properties(self): return {}

commit_message:
Use an ovs port on the overcloud test network

Use an ovs internal port on the overcloud network, the dummy device
doesn't work.

commit_message:
Set glance control_exchange to 'glance'

Glance control_exchange in glance-api.conf wasn't set
and glance used default value for this - 'openstack'.
So, exchange 'glance' and queue 'glance' didn't exist in rabbit.
But ceilometer as default glance control exchange uses 'glance'.
This patch fixes the fix for this problem and change-id as well

Closes-bug: #1335891

Change-Id: Idd1566dd507878b2f01c2d0ff9956dedc77a4461
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/63/108463/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $control_exchange = 'glance', 'DEFAULT/control_exchange': value => $control_exchange; } glance_api_config {

commit_message:
Test illustrating apparent over-aggressive truncation

We do not seem to honour the archive contract in terms of
the number of aggregated datapoints retained.

Change-Id: I7685fe9d095d4f62e6f95d9c19b9388b2f53bb2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi refs/changes/39/108039/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_truncation(self): # start with an empty timeseries with a single (60, 3600) archive, # as it would be stored d = {'timeserie': {'values': {}, 'timespan': u'120S'}, 'archives': [{'aggregation_method': u'mean', 'block_size': u'60S', 'values': {}, 'max_size': 3600, 'sampling': u'60S'}]} # inject single datspoints 61s apart, round-triping to and from # the storage representation on each iteration for i in xrange(1, 11): timeseries = carbonara.TimeSerieArchive.from_dict(d) measures = timeseries.fetch() self.assertEqual(i - 1, len(measures)) timeseries.set_values([ (datetime.datetime(2014, 1, 1, 12, i, i), float(i)) ]) d = timeseries.to_dict() # since we could keep up to 3600 acrhived datapoints, we # expected all 10 of the *aggregated* (as opposed to raw) # datapoints not to be discarded self.assertEqual(i, len(d['archives'][0]['values']))

subject: Fix for unneccessary resampling of single-value timeseries
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-18 14:10:46.000000000', 'files': ['gnocchi/tests/test_carbonara.py', 'gnocchi/carbonara.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/4df82e50aa9a6140845659d7d3ee7e26cca22ef7', 'message': 'Fix for unneccessary resampling of single-value timeseries

Resampling a timeseries with one element is unnecessary,
and causes problems in the case of an aggregated timeseries
with aggregation method set to stddev, as the single already-
aggregated value is then discarded due to standard deviation
being undefined for a single datapoint.

The new test fails with the original unselective resampling.

'}]
commit_message:
Fix for unneccessary resampling of single-value timeseries

Resampling a timeseries with one element is unnecessary,
and causes problems in the case of an aggregated timeseries
with aggregation method set to stddev, as the single already-
aggregated value is then discarded due to standard deviation
being undefined for a single datapoint.

The new test fails with the original unselective resampling.

Change-Id: I7f0db8050c0cef5eceec24977e4cb02d4843824d

commit_message:
Validate available services regions

This introduces middleware that is used to validate the
available services regions. It makes sure that the initial
region has a compute service and is reachable. If a region
does not provide a compute service endpoint it will be
removed from the list of available regions. If there are no
regions with a compute service endpoint or none of them can be
reached then the user will be redirected to the login page with
a message.

Closes-Bug: 1323811
Change-Id: I31c7d70f49f82b6a7fe663fe043ec279ad3c8119

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from django.conf import settings from novaclient.v1_1 import client as nova_client from openstack_dashboard import api def novaclient(request, region): """Get a nova client for a compute endpoint in a specific region. """ url = api.base.url_for(request, 'compute', region=region) insecure = getattr(settings, 'OPENSTACK_SSL_NO_VERIFY', False) cacert = getattr(settings, 'OPENSTACK_SSL_CACERT', None) c = nova_client.Client(request.user.username, request.user.token.id, project_id=request.user.tenant_id, auth_url=url, insecure=insecure, cacert=cacert, http_log_debug=settings.DEBUG) c.client.auth_token = request.user.token.id c.client.management_url = url return c def is_region_reachable(request, region): """Check if the compute service endpoint is reachable for the given region. This is done by using the nova client to request servers. """ client = novaclient(request, region) try: client.servers.list(detailed=False, limit=1) except Exception: return False return True

commit_message:
Implement retry on NodeLocked exceptions

This adds the capability to retry node locking when a node is already
locked. Two conductor configuration variables are added to control this
behavior, which can be totally disabled by setting the value for the
node_locked_retry_attempts variable to zero.

A new unit test is added to check that the retry will work after first
getting a NodeLocked exception, then succeeding getting the lock on the
next lock attempt.

Change-Id: I60b099beea1bc3a954a5ab4699e623aaa71ba6c5
Blueprint: add-nodelocked-retry
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/10/107710/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import retrying # NodeLocked exceptions can be annoying. Let's try to alleviate # some of that pain by retrying our lock attempts. The retrying # module expects a wait_fixed value in milliseconds. @retrying.retry( retry_on_exception=lambda e: isinstance(e, exception.NodeLocked), stop_max_attempt_number=CONF.conductor.node_locked_retry_attempts, wait_fixed=CONF.conductor.node_locked_retry_interval * 1000) def reserve_node(): LOG.debug(_("Attempting to reserve node %(node)s"), {'node': node_id}) self.node = self._dbapi.reserve_node(CONF.host, node_id) reserve_node()

commit_message:
Fix a few bugs when running with -u

The default conf file locator needed to reference the file another level up.

The config file set/write did not work if more than one option was changed.
I'm not sure why but think it would be better to just read once, set the
options, and write at the end anyway.

If we are updating and a service is there but not mentioned in the conf file,
we change the conf to True so should also add the service to the available
services.

Change-Id: I261f4ba08083cb7ed60c0a5bdd48a4dc16f4c23d

commit_message:
Fix install_ceilometer and install_ceilometerclient

Other projects do a setup_develop in install_*. This standard is used by
grenade to do installations. Currently grenade uses install ceilometer
as part of the upgrade script, but this doesn't actually install the new
ceilometer.

Change-Id: I4e44bec6574e6a4fcfc252418bc267191aef28fb
Closes-Bug: #1347178

commit_message:
Read template's expected value orchest test Part-1

In tests under /tempest/api/orchestration/, resources gets
created based on parameters defined in template (yaml, json).
But while verification of output, expected values are hard coded
in tests. Expected values should be read from template only.

This patch adds the helper to load the values from template
(yaml, json) and apply the changes in
tempest/api/orchestration/test_volumes.py

This patch also rename the existing load_template() function
as it read the template and newly added function load the template
This rename the load_template() to read_template in
tempest/api/orchestration/base.py and corresponding calling files.

Partial-Bug: #1327919

Change-Id: Ie0817e20cb7bacdf33b16fb222a7ee9c91109fc8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/76/98676/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import jsonimport yaml def read_template(cls, name, ext='yaml'): loc = ["stacks", "templates", "%s.%s" % (name, ext)] fullpath = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), *loc) with open(fullpath, "r") as f: if ext is 'yaml': content = yaml.load(f) elif ext is 'json': content = json.load(f) else: msg = ("Unexpected extension is specified (%s)" % ext) raise exceptions.InvalidConfiguration(message=msg) return content @classmethod

commit_message:
Fixes bad performance when editing project members

The bug is caused by consecutive client calls when
fetching users' roles in a project.

The fix was to use the /v3/role_assignments endpoint.
Which retrieves all roles in a single client call
(dashboards/admin/projects/workflows.py:
UpdateProjectGroupsAction and UpdateProjectUsersAction).

The compatibility to the previous keystoneclient version
is maintained.

In a scenario with 1000 users with a role in a project
(using devstack), the time to render the Modify Users
page dropped from 45s to 2.5s

Change-Id: Ic72ebea0db226faf98c5e04d00d76dedd1fb01c1
Closes-bug: #1278920
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/12/92412/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def role_assignments_list(request, project=None, user=None, role=None, group=None, domain=None, effective=False): manager = keystoneclient(request, admin=True).assignments return manager.list(project=project, user=user, role=role, group=group, domain=domain, effective=effective)

commit_message:
Fixing data processing image registry

The Data Processing Image Registry was not adapted to use
expect the "previous" return value from glance.image_list_detailed.
This change allows the Image Registry to work correctly again.

Change-Id: I990962483197f54ee9436278463c4709b909297a
Closes-Bug:  #1347036
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/12/108812/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Revert "Add tests for wait_for_server_status"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-07-22 18:39:14.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/tests/test_waiters.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/a6b0a2f1290a8c9343869558f1fe7ed860f76899', 'message': 'Revert "Add tests for wait_for_server_status"

This unit test class added several race conditions to the unit tests as well as
added a dependency on having a valid tempest config file. At this point instead
of trying to fix all of these issues I'm pushing a revert in the short term and 
long-term we can just fix things and re-push these tests.

This reverts commit ae7c9ac4aac20a2832fe1beeaac0a688c6accbd9.

Change-Id: If6026611f3938be0716ce95491a8ee60a53e8c12
Closes-Bug: #1347096
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Add tests for wait_for_server_status"

This unit test class added several race conditions to the unit tests as well as
added a dependency on having a valid tempest config file. At this point instead
of trying to fix all of these issues I'm pushing a revert in the short term and 
long-term we can just fix things and re-push these tests.

This reverts commit ae7c9ac4aac20a2832fe1beeaac0a688c6accbd9.

Change-Id: If6026611f3938be0716ce95491a8ee60a53e8c12
Closes-Bug: #1347096
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/00/108800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines:
import testtools class TestServerWaiters(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestServerWaiters, self).setUp() self.client = mock.MagicMock() self.client.build_timeout = 1 self.client.build_interval = 1 def test_wait_for_server_status(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'active'} ) start_time = int(time.time()) waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active' ) end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns before build_timeout self.assertTrue((end_time - start_time) < 2) def test_wait_for_server_status_BUILD_from_not_UNKNOWN(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'active'}) start_time = int(time.time()) waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'BUILD') end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns before build_timeout self.assertTrue((end_time - start_time) < 2) def test_wait_for_server_status_ready_wait_with_BUILD(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'BUILD'}) start_time = int(time.time()) waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'BUILD', True) end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns before build_timeout self.assertTrue((end_time - start_time) < 2) def test_wait_for_server_status_ready_wait(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'ERROR', 'OS-EXT-STS:task_state': 'n/a' } ) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'active status and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (1 s).
Current status: SUSPENDED.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) self.assertRaises(exceptions.BuildErrorException, waiters.wait_for_server_status, self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=True, extra_timeout=0, raise_on_error=True ) def test_wait_for_server_status_no_ready_wait(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'ERROR', 'OS-EXT-STS:task_state': 'n/a' } ) start_time = int(time.time()) waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'ERROR', ready_wait=False, extra_timeout=10, raise_on_error=True ) end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns before build_timeout + extra_timeout self.assertTrue((end_time - start_time) < 12) def test_wait_for_server_status_timeout(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'SUSPENDED'}) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'active status and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (1 s).
Current status: SUSPENDED.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) self.assertRaises(exceptions.TimeoutException, waiters.wait_for_server_status, self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active') def test_wait_for_server_status_extra_timeout(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'SUSPENDED'}) start_time = int(time.time()) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'active status and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (10 s). 
Current status: SUSPENDED.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) self.assertRaises(exceptions.TimeoutException, waiters.wait_for_server_status, self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=True, extra_timeout=10, raise_on_error=True ) end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns after build_timeout but # before build_timeout+extra timeout self.assertTrue(10 < (end_time - start_time) < 12) def test_wait_for_server_status_error_on_server_create(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'ERROR'}) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'activestatus and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (1 s).
Current status: ERROR.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) self.assertRaises(exceptions.BuildErrorException, waiters.wait_for_server_status, self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active') def test_wait_for_server_status_no_raise_on_error(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'ERROR'}) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'activestatus and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (1 s).
Current status: ERROR.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) self.assertRaises(exceptions.TimeoutException, waiters.wait_for_server_status, self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=True, extra_timeout=0, raise_on_error=False ) def test_wait_for_server_status_no_ready_wait_timeout(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'ERROR'}) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'active status and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (11 s).
Current status: ERROR.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) expected_msg = '''Request timed out Details: (TestServerWaiters:test_wait_for_server_status_no_ready_wait_timeout)\ Server fake_svr_id failed to reach active status and task state "n/a" within\ the required time (11 s). Current status: ERROR. Current task state: None.\ ''' with testtools.ExpectedException(exceptions.TimeoutException, testtools.matchers.AfterPreprocessing( str, testtools.matchers.Equals(expected_msg) ) ): waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=False, extra_timeout=10, raise_on_error=False ) def test_wait_for_server_status_ready_wait_timeout(self): self.client.get_server.return_value = (None, {'status': 'ERROR'}) self.client.get_console_output.return_value = (None, {'output': 'Server fake_svr_id failed to reach ' 'activestatus and task state n/a within the ' 'required time (11 s).
Current status: ERROR.' '
Current task state: None.'} ) expected_msg = '''Request timed out Details: (TestServerWaiters:test_wait_for_server_status_ready_wait_timeout)\ Server fake_svr_id failed to reach active status and task state "None" within\ the required time (11 s). Current status: ERROR. Current task state: None.\ ''' with testtools.ExpectedException(exceptions.TimeoutException, testtools.matchers.AfterPreprocessing( str, testtools.matchers.Equals(expected_msg) ) ): waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=True, extra_timeout=10, raise_on_error=False ) def test_wait_for_changing_server_status(self): self.client.get_server.side_effect = [(None, {'status': 'BUILD'}), (None, {'status': 'active'})] start_time = int(time.time()) waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=True, extra_timeout=10, raise_on_error=True ) end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns before build_timeout + extra_timeout self.assertTrue((end_time - start_time) < 12) def test_wait_for_changing_server_task_status(self): self.client.get_server.side_effect = [(None, {'status': 'BUILD', 'OS-EXT-STS:task_state': 'n/a' } ), (None, {'status': 'active', 'OS-EXT-STS:task_state': 'None' } ) ] start_time = int(time.time()) waiters.wait_for_server_status(self.client, 'fake_svr_id', 'active', ready_wait=True, extra_timeout=10, raise_on_error=True ) end_time = int(time.time()) # Ensure waiter returns before build_timeout + extra_timeout self.assertTrue((end_time - start_time) < 12)

commit_message:
test_heatclient fix mocking with latest keystone

The tests break with latest (0.10.0) keystoneclient, so replace
the mocked domain with a MockAnything object

Change-Id: Icd460e554656e11ef8c4bcda62c1363b7eed8a68
Closes-Bug: #1347319

commit_message:
Add cinder volume driver support for Nimble Storage.

The set of changes introduces the cinder iSCSI volume driver support for
Nimble Storage. It implements the minimum set of features required by the
icehouse release. Please see the blueprint nimble-iscsi-volume-driver for
more information.

Change-Id: I48781fc890b8fefb33027da3db2b1ff56c5deed4
Implements: blueprint nimble-iscsi-volume-driver

added_lines: # Nimble Storage, Inc. © 2013-2014 # Copyright (c) 2014 OpenStack LLC. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. """ Volume driver for Nimble Storage Array. This driver supports Nimble CS-Series controller. """ import math from oslo.config import cfg import suds import hashlib from suds import client from suds.sax import text from cinder import exception from cinder.openstack.common import lockutils from cinder.openstack.common import log as logging from cinder.volume import driver from cinder.volume import volume_types VENDOR_NAME = 'Nimble' DRIVER_VERSION = '1.0' LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) MB_SIZE = math.pow(2, 20) # 2^20 GB_SIZE = math.pow(2, 30) # 2^30 SM_ACL_APPLY_TO_BOTH = 3 SM_ACL_CHAP_USER_ANY = '*' PROTOCOL_ISCSI = 'iSCSI' ISCSI_PORT = '3260' LUN_ID = '0' nimble_opts = [ cfg.StrOpt('nimble_username', default=None, help='Nimble Controller username'), cfg.StrOpt('nimble_password', default=None, help='Nimble Controller password'), cfg.StrOpt('nimble_management_ip_address', default=None, help='Nimble Controller management IP address'), cfg.StrOpt('nimble_pool_name', default=None, help='Nimble Controller pool name'), cfg.StrOpt('nimble_subnet_label', default=None, help='Nimble Subnet Label'), ] class NimbleException(Exception): def __init__(self, msg=None): super(NimbleException, self).__init__(msg) def __str__(self): return '%s' % self.args class NimbleAPIException(NimbleException): pass class NimbleISCSIDriver(driver.ISCSIDriver): """OpenStack driver to enable Nimble Controller. Version history: 2.0 - Initial driver """ def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): super(NimbleISCSIDriver, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) self.APIExecutor = None self.target_ipaddr = None self.configuration.append_config_values(nimble_opts) def _check_flags(self): """Ensure that the flags we care about are set.""" required_flags = ['nimble_management_ip_address', 'nimble_username', 'nimble_password'] for flag in required_flags: if not getattr(self.configuration, flag, None): raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=_('%s is not set.') % flag) def _exception_checker(func): """Checks for any exception occured during operation and returns a common cinder exception """ def _inner_return_value_checker(self, *args, **kwargs): try: return func(self, *args, **kwargs) except Exception, e: msg = _("Operation %s failed: %s" % (func.__name__, str(e))) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=msg) return _inner_return_value_checker def _get_discovery_target(self, netconfig): """Get Automatic Discovery target""" inp_subnet_label = self.configuration.nimble_subnet_label if self.configuration.nimble_subnet_label else '*' LOG.info(_('User input subnet_label %s') %inp_subnet_label) ret_target_ip = None for subnet in netconfig['subnet-list']: LOG.info(_('Exploring subnet label %s'), %subnet['label']) if inp_subnet_label == '*': if (subnet['subnet-id']['type'] == "SM-subnet-data"): LOG.info(_('Target ip %s found on data subnet %s') %(subnet['discovery-ip'], subnet['label'])) return subnet['discovery-ip'] elif (subnet['subnet-id']['type'] == "SM-subnet-mgmt-plus-data"): LOG.info(_('Target ip %s found on mgmt+data subnet %s') %(subnet['discovery-ip'], subnet['label'])) ret_target_ip = subnet['discovery-ip'] elif inp_subnet_label == subnet['label']: LOG.info(_('Target ip %s found on subnet %s') %(subnet['discovery-ip'], subnet['label'])) return subnet['discovery-ip'] if ret_target_ip: LOG.info(_('Target ip %s found on mgmt+data subnet') %ret_target_ip) return ret_target_ip else: raise NimbleException(_("No suitable target ip found")) @_exception_checker def check_for_setup_error(self): pass @_exception_checker def do_setup(self, context): """Setup the Nimble Cinder volume driver.""" self._check_flags() # Setup API Executor try: self.APIExecutor = NimbleAPIExecutor( username=self.configuration.nimble_username, password=self.configuration.nimble_password, ip=self.configuration.nimble_management_ip_address) except Exception, e: LOG.error( _('Failed to create SOAP client. Please make sure the array version is 2.1 and above')) raise netconfig = self.APIExecutor.get_netconfig("active") self.target_ipaddr = self._get_discovery_target(netconfig) @_exception_checker def create_volume(self, volume): """Create a new volume.""" pool_name = self.configuration.nimble_pool_name if self.configuration.nimble_pool_name else 'default' # Create volume self.APIExecutor.create_vol(volume, pool_name=pool_name) def _get_provider_location(self, volume_name): """Get volume iqn for initiator access.""" vol_info = self.APIExecutor.get_vol_info(volume_name) iqn = vol_info['target-name'] iscsi_portal = self.target_ipaddr + ":" + ISCSI_PORT provider_location = '%s %s %s' % (iscsi_portal, iqn, LUN_ID) LOG.info(_('vol_name=%s provider_location=%s' % (volume_name, provider_location))) return provider_location @_exception_checker def delete_volume(self, volume): self.APIExecutor.online_vol(volume['name'], False) self.APIExecutor.delete_vol(volume['name']) @_exception_checker def create_cloned_volume(self, volume, src_vref): """Create a clone of the specified volume.""" raise NimbleException(_("API not implemented")) @_exception_checker def create_export(self, context, volume): """Driver entry point to get the export info for a new volume.""" LOG.info(_("Entering create_export volume=%s") % volume['name']) return ( {'provider_location': self._get_provider_location(volume['name'])} ) @_exception_checker def ensure_export(self, context, volume): """Driver entry point to get the export info for an existing volume.""" LOG.info(_("Entering ensure_export volume=%s") % volume['name']) return ( {'provider_location': self._get_provider_location(volume['name'])} ) @_exception_checker def remove_export(self, context, volume_id): """Driver entry point to remove an export for a volume.""" LOG.info(_("remove_export volume_id=%s.") % volume_id) @_exception_checker def create_snapshot(self, snapshot): """Create a snapshot.""" self.APIExecutor.snap_vol(snapshot) @_exception_checker def delete_snapshot(self, snapshot): """Delete a snapshot.""" self.APIExecutor.online_snap( snapshot['volume_name'], False, snapshot['name'], ignore_list=['SM-ealready']) self.APIExecutor.delete_snap(snapshot['volume_name'], snapshot['name']) @_exception_checker def create_volume_from_snapshot(self, volume, snapshot): """Create a volume from a snapshot.""" pool_name = self.configuration.nimble_pool_name if self.configuration.nimble_pool_name else 'default' self.APIExecutor.clone_vol(volume, snapshot, pool_name) @_exception_checker def get_volume_stats(self, refresh=False): """Get volume stats. This is more of getting group stats.""" group_info = self.APIExecutor.get_group_config() total_capacity = group_info['usableCapacity'] / GB_SIZE used_space = (group_info['volUsageCompressed'] + group_info['snapUsageCompressed']) / GB_SIZE free_space = total_capacity - used_space # Set volume stats data = {"volume_backend_name": self.__class__.__name__, "vendor_name": VENDOR_NAME, "driver_version": DRIVER_VERSION, "storage_protocol": PROTOCOL_ISCSI, "total_capacity_gb": float(total_capacity), "free_capacity_gb": float(free_space), "reserved_percentage": 0, "QoS_support": False } LOG.info(_("total_capacity=%u used_space=%u free_space=%u" % (total_capacity, used_space, free_space))) return data @_exception_checker def extend_volume(self, volume, new_size): """Extend an existing volume.""" volume_name = volume['name'] LOG.info(_("Entering extend_volume volume=%s new_size=%s" % (volume_name, new_size))) vol_size_mask = 4 # SM_change_vol_size vol_size = int(new_size) * GB_SIZE self.APIExecutor.edit_vol( volume_name, vol_size_mask, {'size': long(vol_size)}) def _is_initiator_group_present(self, initiator_group_name): initiator_groups = self.APIExecutor.get_initiator_grp_list() for initiator_group in initiator_groups: if initiator_group['name'] == initiator_group_name: LOG.info(_('Initiator group %s already exists on the array') %initiator_group_name) return True return False @_exception_checker def initialize_connection(self, volume, connector): """Driver entry point to attach a volume to an instance.""" LOG.info(_("Entering initialize_connection volume=%s connector=%s " "location=%s" % (volume, connector, volume['provider_location']))) initiator_name = connector['initiator'] initiator_group_name = "openstack-" + \ hashlib.md5(initiator_name).hexdigest() LOG.info(_('Hashed Initiator group name is %s for initiator %s') %(initiator_group_name, initiator_name)) if not self._is_initiator_group_present(initiator_group_name): LOG.info(_('Creating new initiator group %s on the array with initiator %s') %(initiator_group_name, initiator_name)) self.APIExecutor.create_initiator_group( initiator_group_name, initiator_name) self.APIExecutor.add_acl(volume, initiator_group_name) (iscsi_portal, iqn, lun_num) = volume['provider_location'].split() properties = {} properties['target_discovered'] = False # whether discovery was used properties['target_portal'] = iscsi_portal properties['target_iqn'] = iqn properties['target_lun'] = lun_num properties['volume_id'] = volume['id'] # used by xen currently return { 'driver_volume_type': 'iscsi', 'data': properties, } @_exception_checker def terminate_connection(self, volume, connector, **kwargs): """Driver entry point to unattach a volume from an instance.""" LOG.info(_("Entering terminate_connection volume=%s connector=%s " "location=%s." % (volume, connector, volume['provider_location']))) initiator_name = connector['initiator'] initiator_group_name = "openstack-" + \ hashlib.md5(initiator_name).hexdigest() self.APIExecutor.remove_acl(volume, initiator_group_name) self.APIExecutor.delete_initiator_group( initiator_group_name, ignore_list=['SM-ebusy']) class NimbleAPIExecutor: """Makes Nimble SOAP API calls to a Nimble Controller.""" def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): self.sid = None self.username = kwargs['username'] self.password = kwargs['password'] http_wsdl_url = 'https://%s/wsdl/GroupMgmt.wsdl' % (kwargs['ip']) LOG.info(_('Using Nimble wsdl_url: %s') % http_wsdl_url) self.client = client.Client(http_wsdl_url, username=self.username, password=self.password) http_soap_url = 'http://%s:4210/soap' % (kwargs['ip']) LOG.info(_('Using Nimble soap_url: %s') % http_soap_url) self.client.set_options(location=http_soap_url) #wsdl_url = 'https://%s/wsdl/NsGroupManagement.wsdl' % (kwargs['ip']) # TODO: Temporary workaround. Remove it after the fix https_wsdl_url = 'file:///tmp/NsGroupManagement.wsdl' self.https_client = client.Client(https_wsdl_url, username=self.username, password=self.password) https_soap_url = 'https://%s:5391/soap' % (kwargs['ip']) LOG.info(_('Using Nimble soap_url: %s') % https_soap_url) self.https_client.set_options(location=https_soap_url) self.login() def _response_checker_err_list(func): """Decorator function to check if the responses of an API with error list is positive""" def _inner_response_checker_err_list(self, *args, **kwargs): response = func(self, *args, **kwargs) err_list = response[ 'err-list'] if 'err-list' in response else response['error'] for err in err_list['err-list']: if err['code'] != 0 and err['code'] != "SM-ok": LOG.error( _('API %s failed with error string %s' % (func.__name__, err['code']))) msg = _( _('API %s failed with error string %s') % (func.__name__, err['code'])) raise NimbleAPIException(msg) LOG.info("API %s executed successfully" % func.__name__) return response return _inner_response_checker_err_list @_response_checker_err_list def _execute_login(self): return self.https_client.service.login(req={ 'username': self.username, 'password': self.password }) def login(self): """Execute Https Login API """ response = self._execute_login() LOG.info( _('Successful execution of Login with sid %s') % response['authInfo']) self.sid = response['authInfo']['sid'] return response['authInfo']['sid'] def _connection_checker(func): """Decorator to re-establish and re-run the api if session has expired""" def inner_connection_checker(self, *args, **kwargs): for attempts in range(2): try: return func(self, *args, **kwargs) except NimbleAPIException, e: if attempts < 1 and (str(e).endswith(_("SM-eaccess"))): LOG.info( _('Session might have expired. Trying to relogin')) self.login() continue else: LOG.error(_('Re-throwing Exception %s') % e) raise return inner_connection_checker @_connection_checker @_response_checker_err_list def _execute_get_netconfig(self, name): LOG.info(_("Getting netconfig information for %s") % name) return self.client.service.getNetConfig(sid=self.sid, name=name) def get_netconfig(self, name): """Execute getNetConfig API""" response = self._execute_get_netconfig(name) LOG.info(_('Successfuly retrieved NetConfig for %s') % name) return response['config'] def _response_checker(func): """Decorator function to check if the response of an API is positive""" def inner_response_checker(self, *args, **kwargs): response = func(self, *args, **kwargs) error_code = response['error'] if 'error' in response else response ignore_list = kwargs[ 'ignore_list'] if 'ignore_list' in kwargs else [ ] if error_code != "SM-ok" and error_code not in ignore_list: LOG.error( _('API %s failed with error string %s') % (func.__name__, error_code)) raise NimbleAPIException( _('API %s failed with error string %s') % (func.__name__, error_code)) LOG.info("API %s executed successfully" % func.__name__) return response return inner_response_checker @_connection_checker @_response_checker def _execute_create_vol(self, volume, pool_name): # Set description display_name = volume[ 'display_name'] if 'display_name' in volume else '' display_description = ": " + \ volume[ 'display_description'] if 'display_description' in volume else '' description = display_name + display_description #Limit to 254 characters description = description[:254] # Set volume size volume_size = 100 * MB_SIZE # default to 100 MB if int(volume['size']) != 0: volume_size = int(int(volume['size']) * GB_SIZE) LOG.info(_('Creating a new volume=%s size=%s in pool=%s') % (volume['name'], volume_size, pool_name)) return self.client.service.createVol(sid=self.sid, attr={ 'name': volume['name'], 'description': description, 'size': volume_size, # set default performance # policy 'perfpol-name': 'default', # set default 80% warning 'warn-level': volume_size * 80 / 100, 'quota': volume_size, # default to volume size 'snap-quota': volume_size, # set default volume state # online 'online': True, 'pool-name': pool_name }) def create_vol(self, volume, pool_name): """Execute createVol API """ response = self._execute_create_vol(volume, pool_name) LOG.info(_('Successfuly create volume %s') % response['name']) return response['name'] @_connection_checker @_response_checker def _execute_get_group_config(self): LOG.info(_("Getting group config information")) return self.client.service.getGroupConfig(sid=self.sid) def get_group_config(self): """Execute getGroupConfig API""" response = self._execute_get_group_config() LOG.info(_('Successfuly retrieved group config information')) return response['info'] @_connection_checker @_response_checker def add_acl(self, volume, initiator_group_name): """Execute addAcl API""" LOG.info(_('Adding ACL to volume=%s with initiator group name %s' % (volume['name'], initiator_group_name))) return self.client.service.addVolAcl(sid=self.sid, volname=volume['name'], applyTo=SM_ACL_APPLY_TO_BOTH, chapuser=SM_ACL_CHAP_USER_ANY, initiatorgrp=initiator_group_name) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def remove_acl(self, volume, initiator_group_name): """Execute removeVolAcl API""" LOG.info( _('Removing ACL from volume=%s for initiator group %s' % (volume['name'], initiator_group_name))) return self.client.service.removeVolAcl(sid=self.sid, volname=volume['name'], applyTo=SM_ACL_APPLY_TO_BOTH, chapuser=SM_ACL_CHAP_USER_ANY, initiatorgrp=initiator_group_name) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def _execute_get_vol_info(self, vol_name): LOG.info(_("Getting volume information for vol_name=%s") % (vol_name)) return self.client.service.getVolInfo(sid=self.sid, name=vol_name) def get_vol_info(self, vol_name): """Execute getVolInfo API""" response = self._execute_get_vol_info(vol_name) LOG.info( _('Successfuly got volume information for volume %s') % vol_name) return response['vol'] @_connection_checker @_response_checker def online_vol(self, vol_name, online_flag): """Execute onlineVol API""" LOG.info( _("Setting volume %s to online_flag %s") % (vol_name, online_flag)) return self.client.service.onlineVol(sid=self.sid, name=vol_name, online=online_flag) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def online_snap(self, vol_name, online_flag, snap_name, *args, **kwargs): """Execute onlineSnap API""" LOG.info( _("Setting snapshot %s to online_flag %s") % (snap_name, online_flag)) return self.client.service.onlineSnap(sid=self.sid, vol=vol_name, name=snap_name, online=online_flag) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def delete_vol(self, vol_name): """Execute deleteVol API""" LOG.info(_("Deleting volume %s ") % vol_name) return self.client.service.deleteVol(sid=self.sid, name=vol_name) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def snap_vol(self, snapshot): """Execute snapVol API""" volume_name = snapshot['volume_name'] snap_name = snapshot['name'] # Set description snap_display_name = snapshot[ 'display_name'] if 'display_name' in snapshot else '' snap_display_description = ": " + snapshot['display_description'] if 'display_description' in snapshot else '' snap_description = snap_display_name + snap_display_description #Limit to 254 characters snap_description = snap_description[:254] LOG.info(_("Creating snapshot for volume_name=%s snap_name=%s " "snap_description=%s" % (volume_name, snap_name, snap_description))) return self.client.service.snapVol(sid=self.sid, name=volume_name, attr={ 'name': snap_name, 'description': snap_description}) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def delete_snap(self, vol_name, snap_name): """Execute deleteVol API""" LOG.info(_("Deleting snapshot %s ") % snap_name) return self.client.service.deleteSnap(sid=self.sid, vol=vol_name, name=snap_name) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def clone_vol(self, volume, snapshot, pool_name): """Execute cloneVol API""" volume_name = snapshot['volume_name'] snap_name = snapshot['name'] clone_name = volume['name'] vol_size = volume['size'] snap_size = snapshot['volume_size'] LOG.info(_("Cloning volume from snapshot volume=%s " "snapshot=%s clone=%s vol_size=%s snap_size=%s" % (volume_name, snap_name, clone_name, vol_size, snap_size))) # Check for volume and snapshot size if vol_size != snap_size: LOG.error(_('Failed to create clone with vol_size=%s ' 'snap_size=%s' % (vol_size, snap_size))) msg = _('Cannot create volume of size %s from snapshot of ' 'size %s' % (vol_size, snap_size)) raise NimbleAPIException(msg) vol_size = int(int(volume['size']) * GB_SIZE) # Clone volume from snapshot LOG.info(_('Cloning volume=%s from snapshot=%s in pool=%s' % (volume_name, snap_name, pool_name))) return self.client.service.cloneVol(sid=self.sid, name=volume_name, attr={ 'name': clone_name, 'size': vol_size, # set default performance # policy 'perfpol-name': 'default', # set default warning size 'warn-level': vol_size * 80 / 100, 'quota': vol_size, # default to volume size 'snap-quota': vol_size, # set default volume state # online 'online': True, 'pool-name': pool_name }, **{'snap-name': snap_name}) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def edit_vol(self, vol_name, mask, attr): """Execute editVol API""" LOG.info(_("Editing Volume %s with mask %s") % (vol_name, str(mask))) return self.client.service.editVol(sid=self.sid, name=vol_name, mask=mask, attr=attr) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def _execute_get_initiator_grp_list(self): LOG.info(_("Getting getInitiatorGrpList")) return self.client.service.getInitiatorGrpList(sid=self.sid) def get_initiator_grp_list(self): """Execute getInitiatorGrpList API""" response = self._execute_get_initiator_grp_list() LOG.info(_('Successfuly retrieved InitiatorGrpList')) return response['initiatorgrp-list'] @_connection_checker @_response_checker def create_initiator_group(self, initiator_group_name, initiator_name): """Execute createInitiatorGrp API""" LOG.info( _("Creating initiator group %s with one initiator %s") % (initiator_group_name, initiator_name)) return self.client.service.createInitiatorGrp(sid=self.sid, attr={ 'name': initiator_group_name, 'initiator-list': [{'label': initiator_name, 'name': initiator_name}] }) @_connection_checker @_response_checker def delete_initiator_group(self, initiator_group_name, *args, **kwargs): """Execute deleteInitiatorGrp API""" LOG.info(_("Deleting deleteInitiatorGrp %s ") % initiator_group_name) return self.client.service.deleteInitiatorGrp(sid=self.sid, name=initiator_group_name)

commit_message:
Ensure routing key is specified in the address for a direct producer

This change is already merged in oslo-incubator.  Note that for
Ceilometer this is an Icehouse-specific patch since master has already
been updated to use the oslo.messaging library.

Original commit message body includes:

    Porting this fix from oslo.messaging.  This fixes the impl_qpid.py
    driver to allow it to work with the latest stable upstream QPID broker
    (version 0.28).  See the Apache Qpid Jira bug
    https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/QPID-5557

Change-Id: If71f78e50f8a9b3acfd1e9d02c8271f17c4ebee7
Related-Bug: #1300318
(cherry picked from commit 096106f72fad5975bd0cb8ffa3447931c8fee9f5)

added_lines: def map_reduce_testing(self, cluster_info, check_log=True): if check_log: node_ip_and_process_list = cluster_info['node_ip_list'] have_logs = False for node_ip, process_list in node_ip_and_process_list.items(): if plugin_config.PROCESS_NAMES['tt'] in process_list: self.open_ssh_connection( node_ip, plugin_config.SSH_USERNAME ) try: self.execute_command( './script.sh check_directory -job_name %s' % ( job_name)) have_logs = True except Exception: pass finally: self.close_ssh_connection() if not have_logs: self.fail("Log file of completed 'PI' job on 'tasktracker' or " "'nodemanager' cluster node not found.")

commit_message:
Add ceilometer compute notifications ostf tests

Refactor all ceilometer ostf tests and add tests for
ceilometer compute notifications: memory, vcpus, disk.root.size,
disk.ephemeral.size

Closes-Bug: #1338490
Closes-Bug: #1339105
Partially implements: blueprint ceilometer-ostf-notification-tests

Change-Id: I295b78ae9548e0da18faa4978c5bba78c91f5585

commit_message:
Allow passing kwargs from managers to session

Resource managers may need to pass certain overrides down to the session
layer. The most common example would be to allow them to specify a
different interface to issue a request to than is common. It is possible
later that we may wish to expose this ability to users as well so that
they can choose in there own programs what interface, endpoint name etc
a particular request should be issued to.

Change-Id: I7ee0931d4ea78cf9f463b2f0b54457226c5bea8d

commit_message:
Use correct project/user for quotas

This fixes the compute manager to ensure the proper project_id/user_id
is used when making quota calls by converting most of the compute
manager code to use the new objects. This does not change the RPC
messages to the manager, yet.

Change-Id: I50601d12edef735f3c01ad73445e0826d05efc51
Closes-bug: 1271541
(cherry picked from commit 0a717d7085bd2bca7e5408a5c20e8ae7cd055756)

Attempting to add or remove a list of hosts to an aggregate
results in an internal server error. This patch fixes the input
validation so such a request is correctly rejected and a 400
error returned.

commit_message:
Correctly reject request to add lists of hosts to an aggregate

Attempting to add or remove a list of hosts to an aggregate
results in an internal server error. This patch fixes the input
validation so such a request is correctly rejected and a 400
error returned.

Change-Id: I760db36d685cff20b01a72160b8b3fbb8a70b412
Closes-Bug: #1321653

commit_message:
Make Nova_admin_tenant_id_setter notify neutron-server.

Add notification to ensure that changes in Nova_admin_tenant_id_setter
 will result with neutron-server restarting. This is necessary, otherwise
 it is possible for neutron.conf DEFAULT/nova_admin_tenant_id to not be set
 which will result in odd looking auth failures and cause instances to fail
 booting

Change-Id: Idbb2fe9ce63985e4236e41a642ef1b783bec3753
Closes-bug: #1343009

commit_message:
Enhance versionutils.deprecated to work with classes

If object being decorated has 'func_code' attribute, it is considered
a function (and processed by vanilla versionutils.deprecated),
otherwise a new class is created which logs deprecated message when
class is instantiated. Also 'Juno' release is added to possible
deprecation milestones.

Closes-Bug: #1335800
Change-Id: I12e7ad00af3bac35138cc0f8c7d595a08e8eda03
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/02/103502/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from openstack_dashboard.openstack.common import log from muranodashboard.openstack.common import versionutils LOG = log.getLogger(__name__) class deprecated(versionutils.deprecated): """A decorator to mark both functions and classes as deprecated.""" JUNO = 'J' _RELEASES = { 'F': 'Folsom', 'G': 'Grizzly', 'H': 'Havana', 'I': 'Icehouse', 'J': 'Juno' } def __call__(self, func_or_cls): if hasattr(func_or_cls, 'func_code'): return super(deprecated, self).__call__(func_or_cls) else: if not self.what: self.what = func_or_cls.__name__ + '()' msg, details = self._build_message() class cls(func_or_cls): def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs): LOG.deprecated(msg, details) super(cls, self).__init__(*args, **kwargs) return cls
